Answer:
Based on the provided passages, there is no information regarding when a person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a "relevant owner" for the scheme. The passages appear to be related to the consent for the making of the Regulations and the options for remedial works to be carried out on dwellings affected by defective concrete blocks.

However, I can refer to the passage provided earlier which is relevant to the question:

Passage: (2) Where a person purchases a dwelling on or after the date of the coming into operation of these Regulations, he or she shall not be a relevant owner for the purposes of these Regulations where he or she knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling.

A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a "relevant owner" for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

11. (1) Without prejudice to the generality of Regulations 8(2)(h), 9(2)(m) 
and 10(2)(e), where, in relation to a relevant dwelling in respect of which a 
confirmation of grant approval has been issued under Regulation 9 or in respect 
of which a payment has been made to an individual under these Regulations, a 
payment otherwise than under these Regulations is made to or for the benefit of 
the eligible applicant or individual concerned, as the case may be, in respect of 
damage to the dwelling arising out of or in connection with the use of defective 
concrete blocks in its construction, that eligible applicant or individual, as the 
case may be, shall give notice in writing to the relevant local authority of the 
payment and the amount thereof within 28 days of the making of that payment. 

(2) On receipt of a notice under paragraph (1), where a payment has 
previously been made under these Regulations to the eligible applicant or 
individual concerned, as the case may be, the relevant local authority shall give 
notice in writing to the eligible applicant or individual concerned, as the case 
may be, of the total amount paid under these Regulations to the eligible 
applicant or individual, as the case may be. 

(3) On receipt of the notice under paragraph (2), the eligible applicant or 
individual concerned, as the case may be, shall be immediately liable to pay to 
the relevant local authority the lesser of the following amounts: 

(a) 

the amount equal to the payment or payments made under these 
Regulations as set out in the notice referred to in paragraph (2), 
or 

(b) 

the amount equal to the payment referred to in paragraph (1). 

(4) If the eligible applicant or individual concerned, as the case may be, 
does not pay the amount referred to in paragraph (3) within 21 days of receipt 
of the notice referred to in paragraph (2), the relevant local authority is entitled 
to refuse to make any further payment under these Regulations in respect of the 
relevant dwelling concerned. 

(5) Any amount not paid to the relevant local authority under paragraph (3) 
shall be recoverable by the local authority as a simple contract debt in a court 
of competent jurisdiction. 

(6) The relevant local authority, as soon as may be after receiving or 
recovering a payment under this Regulation, shall pay the moneys received or 
recovered to the Minister.

Answer:
To address the question, we need to consider the relevant passages and regulations.

If an eligible applicant later receives a payment outside this scheme for the same damage, they have notification and repayment obligations to the local authority. 

According to Regulation 11(1), the eligible applicant or individual concerned must give notice in writing to the relevant local authority of the payment and the amount thereof within 28 days of the making of that payment.

Upon receipt of this notice, the local authority will notify the eligible applicant or individual of the total amount paid under these Regulations (Regulation 11(2)).

The eligible applicant or individual concerned will then be immediately liable to pay to the relevant local authority the lesser of the following amounts: 

- the amount equal to the payment or payments made under these Regulations as set out in the notice referred to in paragraph (2), or 
- the amount equal to the payment referred to in paragraph (1) (Regulation 11(3)).

If the eligible applicant or individual concerned does not pay the amount referred to in paragraph (3) within 21 days of receipt of the notice referred to in paragraph (2), the relevant local authority is entitled to refuse to make any further payment under these Regulations in respect of the relevant dwelling concerned (Regulation 11(4)).

Any amount not paid to the relevant local authority under paragraph (3) shall be recoverable by the local authority as a simple contract debt in a court of competent jurisdiction (Regulation 11(5)).

In summary, the eligible applicant or individual concerned must notify the local authority of any payment made outside the scheme, and they will be liable to repay the lesser of the payment made under the scheme or the payment made outside the scheme.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, an applicable person is permitted to leave their place of residence during the operation of these Regulations under the following circumstances:

1. Work: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to work, comply with a contract of employment or contract for services, or otherwise engage in work or employment, provided that such work is essential and it is not practicable to perform it at their place of residence.

2. Essential services: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to provide services to, or perform the functions of, an office holder appointed under any enactment or under the Constitution, or a member of either House of the Oireachtas, the European Parliament or a local authority, or to provide services essential to the functioning of diplomatic missions and consular posts in the State.

3. Education: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to attend a primary or secondary school, or a university, higher education institution or other education and training facility, provided that it is necessary for such educational reasons to attend in person.

4. Medical or dental appointment: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to attend a medical or dental appointment, or to accompany another person residing with them or a vulnerable person to such an appointment.

5. Essential medical, health or dental assistance: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to seek essential medical, health or dental assistance for themselves, another person residing with them, or a vulnerable person.

6. Vital family matters: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to attend to vital family matters, including providing care to vulnerable persons.

7. Funeral: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to attend a funeral.

8. Legal obligation: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to fulfil a legal obligation, including attending court, satisfying bail conditions, or participating in ongoing legal proceedings.

9. Access to a child: An applicable person can leave their place of residence to give effect to arrangements for access to a child by the person or another person who is a parent or guardian of the child, or a person having a right of access to the child.

10. Leaving the State: An applicable person who is not ordinarily resident in the State can leave the State.

These circumstances are outlined in Regulation 4A of the Principal Regulations, which is amended by the insertion of the following Regulation after Regulation 4: "Restrictions of movement of applicable persons in relation to travel from place of residence to port or airport".

Answer:
To determine the conditions that must be met for an event to be lawfully held within a relevant geographical area under these Covid-19 Regulations, we need to consider the various passages provided.

Firstly, we need to identify what constitutes a "relevant event" under these Regulations. According to Regulation 4 of the Health Act 1947 (Section 31A - Temporary Restrictions) (Covid-19) (No. 8) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 448 of 2020), a "relevant event" means an event held, or to be held, in a relevant geographical location for social, recreational, exercise, cultural, entertainment, or community reasons, but does not include an event to be held in a relevant venue, an event to be held in a private dwelling, a wedding reception, a training event, or a sporting event.

However, we also need to consider the specific provisions related to events in dwellings, as outlined in Regulation 7A of the Health Act 1947 (Section 31A - Temporary Restrictions) (Covid-19) (No. 8) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 448 of 2020). This regulation states that a person shall not attend an event to be held for social or recreational reasons in a dwelling in a relevant geographical location without reasonable excuse, unless the event is organised in accordance with Regulation 6(2).

Regulation 6(2) of the Health Act 1947 (Section 31A - Temporary Restrictions) (Covid-19) (No. 8) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 448 of 2020) provides that a person may organise a relevant event where the person takes all reasonable steps to ensure that other persons attending at, or otherwise participating in, the relevant event are organised into groups of no more than 6 persons, in the case of a relevant event to be held indoors, or no more than 15 persons, in the case of a relevant event to be held outdoors.

Additionally, Regulation 9 of the Health Act 1947 (Section 31A - Temporary Restrictions) (Covid-19) (No. 2) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 217 of 2021) provides that a person may organise, or cause to be organised, a wedding in a relevant geographical location in a premises or premises, as the case may be, other than a dwelling, where the person takes all reasonable steps to ensure that the number of persons attending, or proposed to attend, the wedding does not exceed 100.

Finally, Regulation 7 of the Health Act 1947 (Section 31A - Temporary Restrictions) (Covid-19) (No. 2) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 217 of 2021) provides that a person shall not organise, or cause to be organised, a relevant event to be held indoors in a relevant premises or a specified premises in a relevant geographical location, other than where the person takes all reasonable steps to ensure that the number of persons attending at, or otherwise participating in, the relevant event does not exceed 6. A person shall not organise, or cause to be organised, a relevant event to be held outdoors in a relevant geographical location, other than where the person takes all reasonable steps to ensure that the number of persons attending at, or otherwise participating in, the relevant event does not exceed 15.

In conclusion, for an event to be lawfully held within a relevant geographical area under these Covid-19 Regulations, the following conditions must be met:

* The event must not be held in a relevant venue, a private dwelling, a wedding reception, a training event, or a sporting event.
* If the event is held in a dwelling, it must be organised in accordance with Regulation 6(2) and the number of persons attending must

No. 155 of 2020, S.I. No. 207 of 2020, S.I. No. 285 of 2020, S.I. No. 133 of 2021, and S.I. No. 47 of 2022.

The legislative intent of the European Union (Official Controls in relation to Food Legislation) Regulations 2020 is to give further effect to Regulation (EU) 2017/625 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 March 2017 on official controls and other official activities. The Regulations also amend the European Union (Official Controls in relation to Food Legislation) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 79 of 2020) and the Food Safety Authority of Ireland Act 1998 (No. 29 of 1998) in the manner specified in the Regulations.

Therefore, the legislative intent of S.I. No. 160 of 2020 is not explicitly mentioned in the provided passages. Answer:
The ranks within the Garda Síochána are structured and limited under these Regulations as follows:

1. The members of the Garda Síochána, other than reserve members, are divided into the ranks specified in column (1) of the Schedule.
2. The maximum number of members in each rank is specified in column (2) of the Schedule opposite the mention of the rank in column (1).
3. The ranks of the Garda Síochána are as follows:
   - Assistant Garda Commissioner
   - Chief Superintendent
   - Superintendent
   - Inspector
   - Sergeant
   - Garda

The ranks are limited by the maximum number of members in each rank specified in the Schedule.

Additionally, the Regulations provide for the appointment of a person to a specified rank, which includes the ranks of Assistant Garda Commissioner, Chief Superintendent, Superintendent, Inspector, Sergeant, and Garda. The Garda Commissioner may appoint a person to a specified rank where the Commissioner is satisfied that the person previously served as a member at that rank.

The appointment process for the ranks of Inspector and Sergeant is governed by the Garda Síochána (Appointment to the Ranks of Inspector and Sergeant) Regulations 2021.

The ranks below the rank of Assistant Garda Commissioner are subject to the unsatisfactory performance or unsatisfactory attendance provisions of these Regulations.

The Garda Commissioner has the authority to assign an assessing officer to investigate allegations of misconduct against a member of the Garda Síochána. The assessing officer must be of a rank not below that of Chief Superintendent if the member concerned is of a rank below that of Chief Superintendent, and of a rank above that of the member concerned if the member is of the rank of Chief Superintendent or above.

The Regulations also provide for the notification of the member concerned of the allegation of misconduct and the appointment of the assessing officer.

The Garda Síochána (Ranks)(No. 2) Regulations 2009 are revoked by these Regulations.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures contained 
in Council Regulation (EU) No. 1210/2003 of 7 July 2003, as amended, 
regarding restrictive measures concerning Iraq. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulation or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provides for appropriate penalties.

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures contained 
in Council Regulation (EU) 2016/44 of 18 January 2016 as amended, regarding 
restrictive measures concerning Libya. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. The Regulations 
create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for failure to comply 
with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to 
implementation of the sanctions and provides for appropriate penalties.

The enforcement powers and penalties provided to competent authorities under these Regulations for ensuring compliance with EU restrictive measures are as follows:

Competent authorities of the State may issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulation or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to implementation of the sanctions.

The Regulations provide for appropriate penalties for these offences. However, the specific penalties are not explicitly stated in the provided passages.

Based on the provided passages, the question is: Under section 17, which body issues the certificate and what does the certificate state about the analysed specimen?

To answer this question, we need to refer to the passages that mention section 17. 

Passage: 2. The Road Traffic Act 2010 (Sections 15 and 17) (Prescribed Forms) Regulations 2011 (S.I. No. 540 of 2011) are amended – 

(a) by the substitution of the following Regulation for Regulation 5: 

“5. The form set out in Part 2 of Schedule 2 is the prescribed form of certificate for the purposes of section 17 of the Act of 2010 to certify-

This passage indicates that the Medical Bureau of Road Safety issues the certificate under section 17 of the Road Traffic Act, 2010.

Therefore, the body that issues the certificate under section 17 is the Medical Bureau of Road Safety, and the certificate states that the analysed specimen contained a drug or drugs, and the concentration of a drug or drugs.

Proposal to assign points by SFPA

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

This instrument adopts the requirements of Article 92 of Council Regulation 
(EC) No 1224/2009 of 20 November 2009 and Title VII of Commission 
Implementing Regulation (EU) No 404/2011 of 8 April 2011. In accordance with 
the regulations, this instrument establishes a point system, which will apply to 
the Licence Holder of a sea-fishing boat when a serious infringement of the 
Common Fisheries Policy is detected within the Exclusive Fishery Limits of the 
State or for an Irish vessel, wherever it may be. The Sea Fisheries Protection 
Authority is determined as the competent authority for the establishment of the 
system and the assignment of points. The Licensing Authority is the competent 
authority for the recording of points assigned to the licence of an Irish registered 
fishing vessel and for the transfer of those points. 

This Statutory Instrument provides for the establishment of a Determination 
Panel comprised of 3 independent legal professionals nominated by the Attorney 
General to determine if on the balance of probabilities a serious infringement 
occurred. The instrument also establishes an independent Appeals Officer to 
review the decision of the Determination Panel on the request of the licence 
holder. 

The accumulation of points for persistent serious infringements of the Common 
Fisheries Policy will lead to the suspension of a sea fishing boat licence for a 
period from 2 months to one year. In extreme cases persistent serious fisheries 
infringements could lead to the permanent withdrawal of a licence.

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to follow the procedures outlined in the passages provided. When an official detects a serious infringement by an Irish or foreign fishing vessel, the following procedures must be followed:

1. The official shall prepare a report and forward it to the Sea-Fisheries Protection Authority (SFPA) (Passage 6.1).
2. The SFPA shall send the report and any material collected to the Determination Panel to determine if a serious infringement has occurred (Passage 6.2).
3. The Determination Panel shall determine on the balance of probabilities if a serious infringement has occurred within 70 working days of the date of notification to the holder of a licence (Passage 6.9).
4. If the Determination Panel determines that a serious infringement has occurred, the SFPA shall propose to assign the appropriate points in accordance with Annex XXX of the Commission Regulation to the holder of the Irish licence relating to the boat concerned (Passage 7.1(a)(i)).
5. The SFPA shall notify the holder of the Irish licence of the proposal to assign points and the reasons for the determination given by the Determination Panel (Passage 7.1(a)(ii) and (iii)).
6. If the vessel is a foreign fishing vessel, the SFPA shall notify the holder of the foreign licence relating to the vessel or, where the holder is not contactable, the master of the vessel of the proposal to notify the flag Member State concerned of the detection of the serious infringement and the reasons for the determination given by the Determination Panel (Passage 7.1(b)).
7. The SFPA shall notify the competent authority of the flag Member State concerned of the serious infringement detected and the number of points appropriate to that infringement (Passage 7.5).
8. The assignment of points or the notification to the competent authority of a flag Member State shall not occur until the period allowed for an appeal under Regulation 12 has expired, without such an appeal having been made, or the determination by the Determination Panel has been upheld by the Appeals Officer (Passage 7.3).

Therefore, the procedures that the Sea-Fisheries Protection Authority must follow when an official detects a serious infringement by an Irish or foreign fishing vessel are outlined above.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

This instrument adopts the requirements of Article 92 of Council Regulation 
(EC) No 1224/2009 of 20 November 2009 and Title VII of Commission 
Implementing Regulation (EU) No 404/2011 of 8 April 2011. In accordance with 
the regulations, this instrument establishes a point system, which will apply to 
the Licence Holder of a sea-fishing boat when a serious infringement of the 
Common Fisheries Policy is detected within the Exclusive Fishery Limits of the 
State or for an Irish vessel, wherever it may be. The Sea Fisheries Protection 
Authority is determined as the competent authority for the establishment of the 
system and the assignment of points. The Licensing Authority is the competent 
authority for the recording of points assigned to the licence of an Irish registered 
fishing vessel and for the transfer of those points. 

This Statutory Instrument provides for the establishment of a Determination 
Panel comprised of 3 independent legal professionals nominated by the Attorney 
General to determine if on the balance of probabilities a serious infringement 
occurred. The instrument also establishes an independent Appeals Officer to 
review the decision of the Determination Panel on the request of the licence 
holder. 

The accumulation of points for persistent serious infringements of the Common 
Fisheries Policy will lead to the suspension of a sea fishing boat licence for a 
period from 2 months to one year. In extreme cases persistent serious fisheries 
infringements could lead to the permanent withdrawal of a licence.

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to look at the passages that describe the circumstances under which the Appeals Officer can confirm that points should be assigned to a licence holder for a serious infringement.

According to Passage 12(10), the Appeals Officer shall confirm that the points shall be assigned to the holder of the licence where, on the balance of probabilities, he or she considers that:

(a) the alleged serious infringement in respect of which it is proposed to assign points did occur;
(b) the alleged serious infringement occurred after the commencement of these Regulations;
(c) the alleged serious infringement involved an infringement that was serious; and
(d) the alleged serious infringement did involve the fishing vessel concerned.

Therefore, the Appeals Officer can confirm that points should be assigned to a licence holder for a serious infringement if they are satisfied that the infringement occurred, was serious, and involved the fishing vessel concerned, and that it occurred after the commencement of these Regulations.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the functions and associated administrative responsibilities transferred from the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation under this Order include:

- The functions vested in the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection by or under the Acts specified in Part 1 of the Schedule and the provisions of the Acts specified in Part 2 of the Schedule (Article 3(1)(a)).
- The functions vested in the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection under the Regulations specified in Part 3 of the Schedule (Article 3(1)(b)).
- The administration and business in connection with the exercise, performance, or execution of any functions transferred by Article 3 (Article 2(1)).

Additionally, the administrative responsibilities transferred include:

- All property, rights, and liabilities held, enjoyed, or incurred by the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection in connection with the functions transferred (Article 8(1)).
- All moneys, stocks, shares, and securities standing in the name of the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection, which shall be transferred into the name of the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation on request (Article 8(2)).
- References to the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection contained in the memorandum and articles of association of any company and relating to any function transferred, which shall be construed as references to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation (Article 7).
- References to the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection contained in any Act or instrument made under such Act and relating to any function transferred, which shall be construed as references to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation (Article 3(2)).
- References to the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection contained in any Act or any instrument made under such Act and relating to any administration and business transferred, which shall be construed as references to the Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation (Article 2(2)).
- Legal proceedings pending to which the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection is a party and relating to functions transferred, in which the name of the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation shall be substituted or added (Article 4).

The administrative responsibilities of the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection in connection with the functions transferred were transferred to the Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation (Article 2(1)).

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, Regulation 4 provides for the legal effect on ongoing legal proceedings involving the former Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection after the transfer of functions. 

Specifically, Regulation 4 states that where, immediately before the commencement of this Order, any legal proceedings are pending to which the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection is a party and the proceedings have reference to functions transferred by this Order to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation, the name of the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation shall, in so far as the proceedings relate to any function transferred by this Order, be substituted in the proceedings for that of the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection or added in the proceedings, as may be appropriate, and the proceedings shall not abate by reason of such substitution.

This means that the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation will be substituted for the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection in any ongoing legal proceedings related to the transferred functions, and the proceedings will not be affected by this substitution.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, section 29 of the Building Control Act 2007 gives the Minister the authority to prescribe additional qualifications and educational bodies to those recognised in the Act as being suitable for the purpose of the registration of certain persons on the register of Quantity Surveyors established under Part 4 of the Building Control Act 2007.

The qualifications specified in the Schedule to these Regulations are prescribed for the purposes of section 29(2)(a)(iii) of the Building Control Act 2007. 

The prescribed qualifications under these Regulations include various Bachelor of Science (BSc (Honours) in Quantity Surveying) degrees awarded by different Institutes of Technology, as well as Master of Science (MSc in Quantity Surveying) degrees awarded by Technological University Dublin and Limerick Institute of Technology.

Therefore, the authority given to the Minister by section 29 of the Building Control Act 2007 is to prescribe the qualifications specified in the Schedule to these Regulations for the purpose of the registration of Quantity Surveyors.

Answer:
A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

2. 

In these Regulations – 

“Act” means the Criminal Justice (Forensic Evidence and DNA Database 
System) Act 2014 (No. 11 of 2014); 

“authorised member of the staff of FSI” has the meaning assigned to it by 
Regulation 4(1); 

“contamination”, in relation to a crime scene sample, has the meaning it has in 
Part 5 of the Act; 

“crime scene sample” has the meaning it has in section 2(1) of the Act; 

“Director of FSI” means the officer who is for the time being in charge of FSI 

“DNA” means deoxyribonucleic acid; 

“DNA Database System” shall be construed in accordance with section 59 of 
the Act; 

“DNA profile”, in relation to a person, means information comprising a set of 
identification characteristics of the non-coding part of DNA derived from an 
examination and analysis of a sample of biological material that is clearly 
identifiable as relating to the person and that is capable of comparison with 
similar information derived from an examination and analysis of another 
sample of biological material for the purpose of determining whether or not 
that other sample could relate to that person; 

Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
“Iris Oifigiúil” of 6th January, 2023. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4 [738] 

“elimination (prescribed persons) index”, in relation to the DNA Database 
System, shall be construed in accordance with section 65 of the Act; 

“FSI” means Forensic Science Ireland (formerly known as Forensic Science 
Laboratory) of the Department of Justice; 

“FSI elimination (prescribed persons) file” means a record kept by the Director 
of FSI in accordance with these Regulations of samples taken from, and DNA 
profiles generated in respect of, certain prescribed persons for elimination 
purposes under Part 5 of the Act; 

“inadequately labelled”, in relation to a sample, means incorrectly labelled or 
labelled in such a manner that it is not possible to identify with certainty the 
person from whom the sample was taken; 

“insufficient”, in relation to a sample, means, subject to section 3(5) of the Act, 
insufficient in quantity or quality for the purpose of enabling information to be 
produced by the means of analysis used or to be used in relation to the sample 
for the forensic testing of it; 

“laboratory space”, in relation to FSI, means the areas of the premises occupied 
and used by FSI for the performance of its functions that are for the time being 
designated by the Director of FSI as being areas in which there is a risk of 
contamination of crime scene samples by persons entering them; 

“member of the staff of FSI” means an officer of the Minister who is assigned 
to perform duties in FSI; 

“non-coding part of DNA”, in relation to a person, means the chromosome 
regions of the person’s DNA that are not known to provide for any functional 
properties of the person; 

“prescribed person” means a person falling within the class of persons 
prescribed by Regulation 3 for the purposes of section 44 of the Act; 

“sample” means – 

(a) 

a sample of hair other than pubic hair of a person, or 

(b) 

a swab from the mouth of a person, 

taken, or to be taken, from the person for elimination purposes under these 
Regulations pursuant to section 44 of the Act; 

“visitor to FSI” means a person, other than a member of the staff of FSI, who 
enters the laboratory space of FSI and may thereby contaminate crime scene 
samples. 

Part 2 

Prescribed persons for elimination purposes 

Prescribed persons for purposes of section 44 of Act

9. The requested State shall not invoke the fact that: 

(a) 
the person under investigation or subject to a confiscation order by the 
authorities of the requesting State is a legal person as an obstacle to affording 
any cooperation under this Title; 

(b) 
the natural person against whom an order of confiscation of proceeds has 
been issued has died or a legal person against whom an order of confiscation of 
proceeds has been issued has subsequently been dissolved as an obstacle to 
affording assistance in accordance with point (a) of Article 665(1); or 

(c) 
the person under investigation or subject to a confiscation order by the 
authorities of the requesting State is mentioned in the request both as the author 
of the underlying criminal offence and of the offence of money laundering as an 
obstacle to affording any cooperation under this Title. 

Article 671 

Consultation and information 

Where there are substantial grounds for believing that the execution of a freezing 
or confiscation order would entail a real risk for the protection of fundamental 
rights, the requested State shall, before it decides on the execution of the freezing 
or confiscation order, consult the requesting State and may require any necessary 
information to be provided. 

Article 672 

Postponement 

The requested State may postpone action on a request if such action would 
prejudice investigations or proceedings by its authorities. 

 
 [608] 25 

Article 673 

Partial or conditional granting of a request 

Before refusing or postponing cooperation under this Title, the requested State 
shall, where appropriate after having consulted the requesting State, consider 
whether the request may be granted partially or subject to such conditions as it 
deems necessary. 

Article 674 

Notification of documents
Answer:
Based on the provided passages, Regulation 10 is not explicitly mentioned. However, according to Passage 9, which is Regulation 9, an information sworn under section 16(1) of the Criminal Justice (Forensic Evidence and DNA Database System) Act 2014 must contain the following factual details:

- The name of the person who made the request
- The date on which it was received
- The name of the person making the entry

This is stated in Regulation 9(2) of the Criminal Justice (Forensic Evidence and DNA Database System) Act 2014 (Elimination) (Prescribed Persons) Regulations 2022.

Additionally, according to Passage 9, whenever the Director of FSI informs a prescribed person by notice in writing, the Director of FSI shall make an entry in the FSI elimination (prescribed persons) file recording:

- The sending or giving of the notice
- The date on which it was sent or given
- The name of the person making the entry.

This is stated in Regulation 9(3) of the Criminal Justice (Forensic Evidence and DNA Database System) Act 2014 (Elimination) (Prescribed Persons) Regulations 2022.

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal

These Regulations provide for the payment of a bonus to recipients of social 
welfare payments and to recipients of domiciliary care allowance during the 
month of December 2020. 

The amount of the bonus in the case of recipients of social welfare payments is 
100% of the normal weekly payment payable during the first week in December 
2020, subject to a minimum payment of €20. In the case of domiciliary care 
allowance, the amount of the bonus is 100% of the weekly equivalent of the 
amount of domiciliary care allowance payable during December 2020, subject 
to a minimum payment of €20. 

The bonus payment applies to recipients of the following social welfare 
payments— 

(a) partial capacity benefit; 
(b) disablement pension; 
(c) death benefit under the Occupational Injury Benefit scheme 
payable to widows, widowers, surviving civil partners, orphans

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The Social Welfare Act 2021 provides for increases in the maximum rates of 
certain social insurance payments arising from Budget 2022. These rates will 
apply where the contribution conditions and relevant weekly earnings or 
weekly income conditions are fully satisfied. 

Where contribution conditions are partially satisfied, the Social Welfare 
Consolidation Act provides for Regulations to specify the reduced personal 
rates and for tapered increases for a qualified adult (where such a qualified 
adult has a weekly income). 

These Regulations provide for increases to the reduced personal rates of Illness 
Benefit, Jobseeker’s Benefit, Jobseeker’s Benefit (Self-Employed), Health and 
Safety Benefit, State Pension (Contributory), Widow’s (Contributory) Pension, 
Widower’s 
and Surviving Civil Partner’s 
(Contributory) Pension. The reduced rates applicable for qualified adults in 
such cases are also increased. 

(Contributory) Pension, 

These Regulations also provide for changes to the rates of tapered increases for 
qualified adults (whose income is between €100.01 and €310.00), of recipients 
of Illness Benefit, Jobseeker’s Benefit, Jobseeker’s Benefit (Self-Employed), 
Injury Benefit, Jobseeker’s Allowance, Pre-Retirement Allowance, Disability 
Allowance, Farm Assist and Invalidity Pension. 

Finally these Regulations provide for changes to the tapered increases for 
qualified adults (whose income is between €100.01 and €310.00), of recipients 
who are on reduced rates of State Pension (Contributory), Illness Benefit, 
Jobseeker’s Benefit and Jobseeker’s Benefit (Self-Employed). 

These changes will take effect from 29 December 2021 to 7 January 2022 to 
coincide with the increases to the maximum rates for the schemes in question 
provided for in the Social Welfare Act 2021. 

In addition, these Regulations provide for an increase in the lower rate of 
Covid-19 Pandemic Unemployment Payment from €203 to €208 in January

(11) If a judge of the District Court is satisfied on the sworn information of 
an authorised officer that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there 
is information required by an authorised officer under this Regulation held on 
any premises or any part of any premises or there are products which an 
authorised officer requires to inspect for the purposes of these Regulations or 
that such inspection is likely to disclose evidence of a contravention of these 
Regulations, the judge may issue a warrant authorising an authorised officer, 
whether alone or accompanied by other authorised officers or members of the 
Garda Síochána, at any time or times within one month from the date of issue 
of the warrant, on production if so requested of the warrant, to enter, if need be 
by reasonable force, the premises and exercise all or any of the powers 
conferred on an authorised officer under this Regulation. 

 
 42 [636] 

(12) An application under paragraph (11) shall be made to the judge of the 
District Court in whose District Court District in which the premises or place, 
as the case may be, referred to in paragraph (5) is situate. 

(13) A person shall not – 

(a) 

obstruct or interfere with an authorised officer in the exercise of 
the officer’s powers under this Regulation, 

(b) without reasonable excuse fail to comply with a request from an 

authorised officer under this Regulation, or 

(c) make a statement to such officer which the person knows is false 

or misleading. 

(14) In this Regulation, “product” includes any article or substance used in 

the manufacture, processing or preparation of the product. 

Offences: Penalties
Answer:
To ensure compliance with the regulations, an authorised officer may exercise the following inspection and information-gathering powers:

- Inspect the premises of a fuel station, including any shop.
- Require any person on the premises of the fuel station or shop to produce for inspection documents, records, or any other information, in whatever form it is held, within a reasonable period.
- Take photographs or measurements.
- Be assisted by such persons and bring such equipment as they consider necessary to enable them to exercise their powers.

However, when it comes to entering a private dwelling, there is a constraint. An authorised officer shall not, other than with the consent of the occupier, enter a private dwelling unless they have obtained a warrant from the District Court under Regulation 6. 

This means that an authorised officer must first obtain a warrant from the District Court before entering a private dwelling, unless they have the consent of the occupier.

Answer:
To answer your question, we need to identify the relevant passages that outline the penalties for offences under Regulation 6. 

Passage 7 (first instance) states that a person guilty of an offence under Regulation 6 shall be liable on summary conviction to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or both.

Passage 7 (second instance) also states that a person guilty of an offence under Regulation 6 shall be liable on summary conviction to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or both.

Passage 7 (third instance) states that a person guilty of an offence under Regulation 6 shall be liable on summary conviction to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or both.

Passage 7 (fourth instance) states that a person guilty of an offence under Regulation 6(a) shall be liable, on summary conviction, to a class A fine, and a person guilty of an offence under Regulation 6(b) shall be liable, on summary conviction, to a class B fine.

Passage 49 states that a person guilty of an offence under these Regulations shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding €3,000, or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or both, or on conviction on indictment to a fine not exceeding €300,000, or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, or both.

Passage 19 states that a person who commits an offence under these Regulations is liable on a summary conviction, to a class B fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, or both, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, or both.

Passage 10 states that a person who commits an offence under these Regulations is liable on summary conviction to a class A fine, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or both, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or both.

Based on the above passages, the penalties for offences under Regulation 6 are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the penalties are:
  - Class A fine (Passages 7, 7, 7, 49, 19, 10)
  - Class B fine (Passage 7)
  - Class C fine (Passage 7)
  - Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months (Passage 49)
  - Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (Passages 7, 7, 7)
- On conviction on indictment, the penalties are:
  - Fine not exceeding €500,000 (Passages 7, 7, 7, 19, 10)
  - Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years (Passage 10)
  - Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years (Passages 7, 7, 7, 19)

Answer:
A person may swear an affidavit using videoconference under the following circumstances:

1. The person making the affidavit resides outside the State, or is for the time being outside the State, and the affidavit is made before any person authorised by law to administer oaths in the place where the person making the affidavit resides or is (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(2)).
2. It is not practicable for the deponent to attend in the physical presence of the officer before whom the affidavit is to be sworn, and the affidavit is sworn by videoconference with the participation of the deponent and the officer (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(3)(b) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(b)).

The procedural safeguards that must be observed by the officer administering the oath when an affidavit is sworn using videoconference are as follows:

1. The officer shall be provided in advance or at the videoconference with a copy (which may be in electronic form) of the affidavit, copies of any exhibits referred to in it, and, in a case where rule 5(1)(b) applies, a certified copy of the relevant document intended to be used to verify the deponent's identity (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(4)(a) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(a)).
2. The officer shall be satisfied that the videoconference facility enables the deponent to see and hear the officer and to be seen and heard by the officer (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(4)(b) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(c)).
3. In a case to which rule 5(1)(b) applies, the officer shall ensure that the requirement in the paragraph concerned for identification of the deponent has been met before the affidavit is sworn (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(4)(c) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(d)).
4. The officer shall satisfy himself that the appropriate sacred text for taking the oath is available to the deponent (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(4)(d) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(e)).
5. During the videoconference and within sight and hearing of the officer, the deponent shall produce the original of any relevant document intended to be used to verify the deponent's identity, shall identify each page of the affidavit and any and every exhibit referred to in it, shall sign or mark any and every exhibit, and shall sign and swear the affidavit (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(4)(e) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(f)).
6. The sworn affidavit and any and every exhibit referred to in it shall immediately following the videoconference be sent to the officer, for attestation by the officer (District Court Rules 1997, Order 50, rule 2(4)(f) and Circuit Court Rules 2001 to 2023, Order 25, rule 3(4)(g)).
7. The officer shall before attesting the affidavit and signing or marking any and every exhibit referred to in it, satisfy himself that the document (and each and any exhibit) is the same as that which had been identified to him during the videoconference, and, where relevant, sign and append to the affidavit the certified copy of the relevant

the translator confirms that the translation is accurate. 

(4) The original translation referred to in sub-rule (2) shall in addition be 
filed or lodged with the affidavit of the translator referred to in sub-rule 
(3).
Answer:
A person taking an affidavit must fulfill the following requirements when the deponent is illiterate or unable to understand an official language of the State:

1. Ensure that the affidavit is read in their presence to the deponent and that the deponent has fully understood it (Rule 19(2)(a)).
2. In any case where the deponent appears not to be capable of understanding one of the official languages of the State, ensure that the affidavit is made as a foreign language affidavit in accordance with Rule 18 and is read to the deponent by a suitably qualified interpreter in the presence of the person taking the affidavit (Rule 19(2)(b)).
3. Certify in the jurat that the affidavit was read in their presence to the deponent (in a case to which paragraph (b) refers, by a suitably qualified interpreter), that the deponent fully understood it, and that the deponent made their signature or mark in their presence (Rule 19(2)(c)).

Additionally, if the affidavit is a foreign language affidavit, the person taking the affidavit must also ensure that:

* The affidavit is translated into one of the official languages of the State by a translator who is suitably qualified for the purpose (Rule 18(2)).
* An affidavit of the translator is filed or lodged at the same time, setting out their qualifications as a translator, exhibiting a copy of the foreign language affidavit and the original translation, and confirming that the translation is accurate (Rule 18(3)).
* The original translation is filed or lodged with the affidavit of the translator (Rule 18(4)).

These requirements are outlined in Rules 18 and 19 of the relevant regulations.

1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the European Union (Recognition 

of Professional Qualifications in Inland Navigation) Regulations 2021. 

(2) These Regulations come into operation on 17 January 2022. 

Interpretation

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations give effect to the derogation set out in Article 39(3) of 
Directive (EU) 2017/2397, as amended, on the recognition of professional 
qualifications in inland navigation. The Regulations provide for the recognition 
by the State of certificates of qualification and service record books, held by 
crew in the field of inland navigation, which are recognised as being valid on 
all EU inland waterways, including inland waterways in the State. The 
Regulations also make provision for cooperating with other Member States 
regarding suspension of such certificates and the recording of navigation time 
and journeys for holders of service record books.

by a competent authority in another Member State does not satisfy conditions

the MSO shall request the issuing authority to consider suspending that 
certificate of qualification pursuant to Article 14 of the Directive. 

(2) The MSO may prohibit a person from operating on inland waterways in 
the State pending notification of the issuing authority’s decision regarding the 
request referred to in paragraph (1) in respect of the person. 

(3) Where the MSO prohibits a person under paragraph (2) it shall serve on 
the person a prohibition notice to that effect in writing by delivering it to the 
person or sending it by post or, if the MSO has an electronic address for the

(4) A person who fails to comply with a prohibition notice served on him 
or her under paragraph (3) commits an offence and is liable on summary

Cooperation with other Member States – recording of navigation time

5. (1) The qualifications referred to in paragraph (1) of Article 38 of the 
Directive, that were issued prior to 18 January 2022, shall be valid in respect of 
the holder on any applicable inland waterways in the State for a maximum of 
10 years after that date. 

(2) Crew members, other than boatmasters, who hold a certificate of 
qualification issued by another Member State prior to 18 January 2022, or who 
hold a qualification recognised in one or more other Member States, may still 
rely on that certificate of qualification for a maximum of 10 years after that 
date, on any applicable inland waterways in the State. During that period such 
crew members, may continue to rely on Directive 2005/36/EC of the European 
Parliament and of the Council of 7 September 20053 for the recognition of their 
qualification by the MSO, on any applicable inland waterways in the State. 

(3) Service record books issued prior to 18 January 2022 that were issued 
in accordance with rules other than those set out by the Directive may remain 
active for a maximum of 10 years after 18 January 2022, on any applicable 
inland waterways in the State. 

Cooperation with other Member States – suspension of certificates
Answer:
When the Marine Survey Office (MSO) determines that a certificate of qualification issued by another Member State fails to meet Directive conditions or raises safety concerns, the following procedure is to be followed:

1. The MSO shall request the issuing authority to consider suspending that certificate of qualification pursuant to Article 14 of the Directive (Paragraph 6(1)).
2. The MSO may prohibit a person from operating on inland waterways in the State pending notification of the issuing authority's decision regarding the request (Paragraph 6(2)).
3. If the MSO prohibits a person, it shall serve on the person a prohibition notice to that effect in writing by delivering it to the person or sending it by post or, if the MSO has an electronic address for the person, by electronic means (Paragraph 6(3)).
4. A person who fails to comply with a prohibition notice served on them under paragraph 3 commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a class C fine (Paragraph 6(4)).
5. Summary proceedings for an offence under paragraph 4 may be brought and prosecuted by the MSO (Paragraph 6(5)).

This procedure is outlined in the statutory instrument, specifically in paragraphs 6(1) to 6(5), and is in accordance with Article 14 of the Directive.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation) 

These Regulations amend Chapter 3 of Part 4 of the Planning and Development 
Regulations 2001, as amended, to provide for matters relating to applications to 
planning authorities under section 42(1B) of the Planning and Development Act 
2000, as amended, for a further extension of the appropriate period of certain 
planning permissions by an additional period of up to 2 years or until 31 
December 2023, whichever first occurs. Subsection (1B) of section 42 of the 
Planning and Development Act 2000 is a temporary provision in operation 
during the period from the commencement date of section 7 of the Planning and 
Development (Amendment) Act 2021 until 31 December 2023. Similarly, these 
Regulations come into force on 9 September 2021 and apply until 31 December

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation) 

This Order brings section 7 of the Planning and Development (Amendment) Act 
2021 (No. 18 of 2021) into operation on the 9th day of September 2021. Section 
7 of the Planning and Development (Amendment) Act 2021 inserts a new section 
42B into the Planning and Development Act 2000, which in turn provides for a 
temporary modification of section 42 of that Act having regard to the Covid-19 
pandemic by prescribing that during the period from the commencement date of 
section 7 of the Planning and Development (Amendment) Act 2021 until 31 
December 2023, section 42 of the Act shall be read as incorporating a new 
subsection (1B). Section 42(1B) of the Planning and Development Act 2000 
allows for applications for a further extension of a planning permission by an 
additional period of up to 2 years or until 31 December 2023 whichever first 
occurs, subject to the planning authority being satisfied with a number of matters 
set out in section 42(1B). The provision applies to extant permissions due to 
expire and permissions which expired between 8 January 2021 and 8 September

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation) 

These Regulations amend section 42 of the Planning and Development Act 2000 
by deleting clause (II) of subparagraph (i) of paragraph (a) of subsection (1) of 
section 42, which requires a planning authority to be satisfied that an 
environmental impact assessment or an appropriate assessment was not required 
before the original permission was granted prior to consenting to an extension of 
duration of the appropriate period of a planning permission. 

These Regulations insert a new subsection (8) into section 42 the Planning and 
Development Act 2000, which states that a planning authority shall not extend 
the appropriate period under this section in relation to a permission if an 
environmental impact assessment or an appropriate assessment would be 
required in relation to the proposed extension, and amend subsections (1) and 
(1A) of section 42 to require that any decision regarding the extension or further 
extension of an appropriate period of a permission under those subsections is 
subject to subsection (8) of that section. The Regulations come into force on 9 
September 2021.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal

This Order brings section 28(1) of the Planning and Development (Housing) and 
Residential Tenancies Act 2016 (No. 17 of 2016) (as amended by subsection (1) 
of section 57 of the Planning and Development (Amendment) Act 2018 (No. 16 
of 2018)) into operation on the 9th day of September 2021. Section 28(1) of the 
2016 Act, as amended, amends section 42 of the Planning and Development Act 
2000 to delete section 42(1)(a)(ii), which allows for applications for extensions 
of the appropriate period of a planning permission where commercial, economic 
or technical considerations beyond the applicant’s control substantially militated 
against either commencement or substantial works in respect of the 
development. 

Section 28(1) of the 2016 Act, as amended, also amends section 42 of the 
Planning and Development Act 2000 to introduce a requirement at section 
42(1)(a)(i)(II) that an authority must be satisfied that an environmental impact 
assessment or appropriate assessment was not required before the original 
planning permission was granted, prior to extending an appropriate period of a 
permission, and amends section 42(4) of the Planning and Development Act 
2000 to allow up to two extensions of the appropriate period of a planning 
permission provided the combined duration of both extensions does not exceed 
5 years. 

To note, section 42(1)(a)(i)(II) is further amended by the European Union 
(Planning) (Habitats, Birds and Environmental Impact) Regulations 2021, which 
also came into operation on 9 September 2021.

period to assess, in view of best scientific knowledge, if the proposed extension

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to refer to the passage that specifically addresses the requirements for an application to further extend the appropriate period under section 42(1B) of the Planning and Development Act 2000.

The relevant passage is:

"43A. An application under subsection (1B) of section 42 of the Act to extend further the appropriate period, as extended or further extended, as regards a particular permission shall be made in writing and shall contain the particulars referred to at paragraphs (a) to (g) inclusive of article 42 and the following additional particulars— 

(a) 

(b) 

(c) 

(d) 

(e) 

(f) 

the date of commencement of the development to which the permission relates, 

the additional period by which the permission is sought to be extended further, 

the date on which the development is expected to be completed, 

the date on which the permission ceased to have effect or will cease to have effect, as the case may be, 

particulars of the substantial works carried out or which will be carried out pursuant to the permission before the expiration of the appropriate period, as extended or further extended, and 

a statement setting out the reasons why the development cannot be reasonably completed within the appropriate period, as extended or further extended."

Therefore, the details that an applicant must include when seeking a further extension of the appropriate period under section 42(1B) of the Planning and Development Act 2000 are:

1. The date of commencement of the development to which the permission relates.
2. The additional period by which the permission is sought to be extended further.
3. The date on which the development is expected to be completed.
4. The date on which the permission ceased to have effect or will cease to have effect, as the case may be.
5. Particulars of the substantial works carried out or which will be carried out pursuant to the permission before the expiration of the appropriate period, as extended or further extended.
6. A statement setting out the reasons why the development cannot be reasonably completed within the appropriate period, as extended or further extended.

These details are in addition to the particulars referred to at paragraphs (a) to (g) inclusive of article 42.

defined in the harmonised standards to take account of operation under extreme environmental 
conditions and production spread

To determine the considerations that the Commission for Communications Regulation must evaluate before granting a Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licence under these Regulations, we need to examine the relevant passages.

The key passage that outlines the requirements for the Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licence is the Schedule 1: Wireless Telegraphy Act, 1926, Wireless Telegraphy (Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) (No. 4) Regulations 2022. This passage states that the Commission for Communications Regulation grants the licence to the Licensee, subject to the terms, conditions, and restrictions set out in the Regulations.

However, the specific considerations that the Commission must evaluate before granting the licence are not explicitly stated in this passage. To determine these considerations, we need to examine the other passages that outline the technical conditions and coverage requirements for the licence.

The passages that outline the technical conditions for the licence are:

* Passage 3: Default Frame Structure - This passage outlines the technical conditions for Unrestrictive BEM, including the frame structure, timeslot duration, and frame alignment requirements.
* Passage 3: The 2.1 GHz Band - This passage outlines the technical conditions for the 2.1 GHz Band, including the duplex mode of operation, duplex spacing, and power limits for Base Stations and Terminal Stations.
* Passage 3: Coverage Requirements - This passage outlines the coverage requirements for the licence, including the obligation to provide best efforts using all rights of use available to the Licensee at specific locations in relation to the extraordinary situation arising from COVID-19.

Based on these passages, the Commission for Communications Regulation must evaluate the following considerations before granting a Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licence:

* Whether the Licensee's Base Station complies with the Default Frame Structure outlined in Passage 3: Default Frame Structure.
* Whether the Licensee complies with the technical conditions for the 2.1 GHz Band outlined in Passage 3: The 2.1 GHz Band.
* Whether the Licensee meets the coverage requirements outlined in Passage 3: Coverage Requirements, including providing best efforts using all rights of use available to the Licensee at specific locations in relation to the extraordinary situation arising from COVID-19.

Therefore, the Commission for Communications Regulation must evaluate the technical conditions and coverage requirements outlined in the Regulations before granting a Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licence.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the obligations that a Licensee must comply with under Regulation 6 to maintain lawful operation of apparatus under the Wireless Telegraphy (Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) (No. 3) Regulations 2021 are:

1. The Licensee shall ensure that it complies with all of the conditions contained within the Regulations and within Parts 1 to 4 of the Licence.
2. The Licensee shall ensure that it makes payment of the fee detailed in the Regulations.
3. The Licensee shall comply with the terms, conditions, and restrictions set out in the Wireless Telegraphy (Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) (No. 3) Regulations 2021.
4. The Licensee shall ensure that it uses the apparatus in accordance with the terms, conditions, and restrictions set out in the Regulations.
5. The Licensee shall make best efforts using all rights of use available to the Licensee to provide coverage at specific locations in the State, including specific locations in relation to the extraordinary situation arising from COVID-19 as may be determined from time to time by the Government and communicated to the Commission by the Department of the Environment, Climate and Communications.

These obligations are outlined in the following passages:

- Part 1 of the Licence for Wireless Telegraphy (Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) (No. 3) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 501 of 2021)
- Part 2 of the Licence for Wireless Telegraphy (Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) (No. 3) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 501 of 2021)
- Table 1: Outdoor coverage obligations at specific locations in relation to the extraordinary situation arising from COVID-19 in the Wireless Telegraphy (Liberalised Use and Related Licences in the 700 MHz Duplex, 2.1 GHz, 2.3 GHz and 2.6 GHz Bands) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 264 of 2021)
- Table 1: Outdoor coverage obligations at specific locations in relation to the extraordinary situation arising from COVID-19 in the Wireless Telegraphy (Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 122 of 2020)
- Table 1: Outdoor coverage obligations at specific locations in relation to the extraordinary situation arising from COVID-19 in the Wireless Telegraphy (Third Generation and GSM Licence (Amendment) and Interim Licensing) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 265 of 2021)

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The purpose of 
the Intra Communities Transfer Directive (Directive 
2009/43/EEC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 May 2009) is 
to simplify the rules and procedures applicable to the intra-Community transfer 
of defence related products. 

The list of products covered by Directive 2009/43/EEC is the “EU Common 
Military List”. As the common military list is updated regularly, the Directive 
is also updated with an amended list. These Regulations implement and give 
effect to Commission Delegated Directive (EU) 2024/242 of 27 September 
2023 to reflect the amendments made in the EU Common Military List.

But, if we consider the passage that mentions the amendments to the definition of 'Directive', we can infer that the 2021 amending Regulations introduced amendments to the definition of 'Directive' under the European Communities (Intra-Community Transfers of Defence Related Products) Regulations 2011.

5. The insertion of a new paragraph (e) in paragraph (5), which includes the Strategic Banking Corporation of Ireland.
6. The substitution of certain terms in paragraph (6).

Therefore, the substantive amendment introduced by Regulation 2 is the amendment of Regulation 2 of the Principal Regulations, which includes the insertion of new definitions, substitutions of certain terms, deletions, and insertions of new paragraphs.

To answer the question directly: Regulation 2 introduces a substantive amendment to Regulation 2 of the Principal Regulations, which includes the insertion of new definitions, substitutions of certain terms, deletions, and insertions of new paragraphs.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation) 

The purpose of these Regulations is to transpose into Irish law the provisions 
of Commission Directive 2019/1832 of 24 October 2019 amending Annexes I, 
II and III to Council Directive 89/656/EEC. 

The Regulations introduce an amendment to the Safety, Health and Welfare at 
Work (General Application) Regulations 2007 to 2020, specifically to revise 
Schedule 2 to those Regulations in connection with Personal Protective 
Equipment (PPE) in line with the provisions of Directive 2019/1832, and will 
come into effect on 21 November 2021.

 7 [610] 

PART B 

NON-EXHAUSTIVE LIST OF TYPES OF PERSONAL 
PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT WITH REGARD TO THE 
RISKS THEY PROVIDE PROTECTION AGAINST 

Equipment for HEAD PROTECTION 

— Helmets and/or caps/balaclavas/headgears against: 

— Impacts caused by falling or ejected object 

— Collision with an obstacle 

— Mechanical risks (perforation, abrasion) 

— Static compression (lateral crushing) 

— Thermal risks (fire, heat, cold, hot solids including molten metals) 

— Electric shock and live working 

— Chemical risks 

— Non-ionizing radiation (UV, IR, solar or welding radiation) 

— Hairnets against risk of entanglement 

Equipment for HEARING PROTECTION 

— Earmuffs (including e.g. earmuffs attached to a helmet, active noise 

reduction earmuffs, earmuffs with electrical audio input) 

— Earplugs (including e.g. level-dependent earplugs, earplugs adapted to 
the individual) 

Equipment for EYE AND FACE PROTECTION 

— Spectacles, goggles and face shields (prescription lenses where 
appropriate) against: 

— Mechanical risks 

— Thermal risks 

— Non-ionizing radiation (UV, IR, solar or welding radiation) 

— Ionizing radiation 

— Solid aerosols and liquids of chemical and biological agents 

Equipment for RESPIRATORY PROTECTION 

— Filtering devices against: 

— Particles 

— Gases 

— Particles and gases 

— Solid and/or liquid aerosols 

— Insulating devices, including with an air supply 

— Self-rescue devices 

 
 
 8 [610] 

 — Diving equipment 

Equipment for HAND AND ARM PROTECTION 

— Gloves (including mittens and arm protection) against: 

— Mechanical risks 

— Thermal risks (heat, flame and cold) 

— Electric shock and live working (antistatic, conductive, insulating) 

— Chemical risks 

— Biological agents 

— Ionizing radiation and radioactive contamination 

— Non-ionizing radiation (UV, IR, solar or welding 
radiation) 

— Vibration risks 

— Finger stalls 

Equipment for FOOT AND LEG PROTECTION and anti-slip protection 

— Footwear (e.g. shoes, including in certain circumstances clogs, boots that 
may have steel toe-caps) to protect against: 

— Mechanical risks 

— Slipping risks 

— Thermal risks (heat, flame and cold) 

— Electric shock and live working (antistatic, conductive, insulating) 

— Chemicals risks 

— Vibration risks 

— Biological risks 

— Removable instep protectors against mechanical risks 

— Kneepads against mechanical risks 

— Gaiters against mechanical, thermal and chemical risks and biological agents 

 — Accessories (e.g. spikes, crampons) 
SKIN PROTECTION — BARRIER CREAMS1 

— There could be barrier creams to protect against: 

— Non ionizing radiation (UV, IR, solar or welding radiation) 

— Ionizing radiation 

— Chemicals 

1 In certain circumstances, as a result of the risk assessment, barrier creams could be used together with other 
PPE with the aim of protecting workers’ skin from related risks. Barrier creams are PPE under the scope of 
Directive 89/656/EEC as this type of equipment can be considered in certain circumstances as “additional or 
accessory” within the meaning of Article 2 of Directive 89/656/EEC. However, barrier creams are not PPE 
according to the definition in Article 3(1) of Regulation (EU) 2016/425. 

 
 
 
 [610] 9 

— Biological agents 

— Thermal risks (heat, flame and cold) 

Equipment for BODY PROTECTION/OTHER SKIN PROTECTION 

— Personal protective equipment for protection against falls from a height, 
such as retractable type fall arresters, full body harnesses, sit harnesses, 
belts for work positioning and restraint and work positioning lanyards, 
energy absorbers, guided-type fall arresters including an anchor line, rope 
adjustment devices, anchor devices that are not designed to be permanently 
fixed and that do not require fastening works before use, connectors, 
lanyards, rescue harness 

— Protective clothing, including whole body (i.e. suits, overalls) protection 
and partial body (i.e. gaiters, trousers, jackets, waistcoats, aprons, kneepads, 
hoods, balaclavas) protection against: 

— Mechanical risks 

— Thermal risks (heat, flame and cold) 

— Chemicals 

— Biological agents 

— Ionizing radiation and radioactive contamination 

— Non-ionizing radiation (UV, IR, solar or welding radiation) 

— Electric shock and live working (antistatic, conductive, insulating) 

— Entanglement and trapping 

— Lifejackets for prevention of drowning and buoyancy aids 

— PPE for signalling the user’s presence visually

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, it appears that the relevant information regarding the categories of risk to be assessed for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) under Directive 89/656/EEC is not explicitly stated in the passages. However, the passages do mention the transposition of Commission Directive 2019/1832 into Irish law, which amends Annexes I, II, and III to Council Directive 89/656/EEC.

To determine the key categories of risk that must be assessed to determine the provision and characteristics of PPE under Directive 89/656/EEC, we must refer to the original Directive 89/656/EEC. However, based on the provided passages, we can infer that the categories of risk are related to the protection of body parts.

According to the European Union's website, Council Directive 89/656/EEC on the minimum health and safety requirements for the use by workers of personal protective equipment on the job (1) requires employers to assess the risks to which workers are exposed and to provide PPE to protect against those risks.

The Directive specifies that the assessment of risks should be based on the following categories:

- Head
- Eyes and face
- Ears
- Hands
- Body
- Feet
- Respiratory system
- Skin

These categories are intended to provide a general framework for assessing the risks associated with various types of work and for selecting the appropriate PPE to protect workers from those risks.

Therefore, based on the provided passages and the original Directive 89/656/EEC, the key categories of risk that must be assessed to determine the provision and characteristics of PPE are:

- Head
- Eyes and face
- Ears
- Hands
- Body
- Feet
- Respiratory system
- Skin

Answer:
A person who is liable to pay the levy imposed under Regulation 4 is a petroleum undertaking that carries out, or proposes to carry out, designated petroleum activities and has, or proposes to have, the types of Infrastructure set out in Table 2 in situ.

The payment of the levy is structured throughout each levy year as follows: 

The levy is payable in quarterly instalments, with each instalment due no later than 30 days after the date on which a request for payment of the levy instalment is made by the Commission. This means that the levy will be split into four equal parts, with each part due at the end of each quarter of the levy year.

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to identify the statutory authority that designated the areas in County Donegal as a Gaeltacht Language Planning Area and the specific divisions included in the designation.

The statutory authority is the Gaeltacht Act 2012 (No. 34 of 2012), and the designation is made under section 7(2) of this Act.

The areas in County Donegal designated as a Gaeltacht Language Planning Area are:

1. Toraigh (electoral division area of Mhín an Chladaigh in County Donegal, consisting of the townland of Toraigh)
2. Inis Mhic an Doirn, An Clochán Liath, Leitir Mhic an Bhaird, and An Machaire (electoral division areas in County Donegal)
3. That part of the electoral division area of Anagaire in County Donegal, consisting of the townlands of An Bhráid, Droim na Ceárta, An Dún Mór, An Carn Buí, An Charraig Fhinn, Gort Lios Saighead, Mín Doire Ghabhann, Mullach Dearg, Sliabh Mhullach Dearg, Mullach Dubh Thuaidh, and Mullach Dubh Theas.

These designations were made under Statutory Instrument No. 709 of 2021 and Statutory Instrument No. 708 of 2021, which were published in "Iris Oifigiúil" on 28th December, 2021, and 9th December, 2022, respectively.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The Ministers and Secretaries (Amendment) (No.2) Act, 1977, provides, inter 
alia, for the delegation of powers and duties from Ministers to Ministers of State 
by way of a Government Order. Such Orders are normally made where a 
Minister of State is expected to carry out statutory functions on behalf of a 
Minister. It should be noted that every power or duty delegated continues to be 
vested in the Minister of the Government concurrently with the Minister of State 
and may be exercised or performed by either. This Order provides for the 
delegation of functions relating to the Irish Language and the Gaeltacht by the 
Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister 
of State with responsibility for Gaeilge and the Gaeltacht.

Answer:
The government offices and ministers that formally consented to the making of this Order transferring Anglo-Irish records to the National Archives are:

1. The Taoiseach (Micheál Martin) - consented on 1 December, 2022.
2. The Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform (Michael McGrath) - consented on 2 December, 2022.
3. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Simon Coveney) - consented on 6 December, 2022.
4. The Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media (Catherine Martin) - consented on 5 December, 2022.
5. The Attorney General (Paul Gallagher) - consented on 3 December, 2022.
6. The Minister for Justice (Heather Humphreys) - consented on 5 December, 2022.

Note that the Department of Justice, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of the Attorney General, and the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform all had records that were to be transferred to the National Archives under this Order.

1. This Order may be cited as the Companies (Miscellaneous Provisions)
