EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

This Order extends, until 19th June 2020, the operation of the amendments 
effected by Part 2 of the Health (Preservation and Protection and other 
Emergency Measures in the Public Interest) Act 2020 [No. 1 of 2020] to the 
Social Welfare Consolidation Act 2005. These provisions currently expire on 
9th May 2020. 

The effect of the extension is to allow the payment of enhanced Illness Benefit 
to those who are diagnosed with Covid-19 or who are deemed to be a probable 
source of infection of same or by order under the Health Act 1947 until the 19th 
of June. This Order also allows the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social 
Protection to extend until the same date, by regulation, the waiving of the three 
day waiting period for Jobseeker's Benefit and Jobseeker's Allowance.

minimising or slowing the spread of Covid-19. These Regulations amend S.I.

extend the date of operation of S.I. No. 121 of 2020 until 8 June 2020.

Answer:
To answer your question, I will refer to the passages provided, specifically Schedule 4 of the Regulations, which outlines the activities requiring consent from the Minister under Regulation 5.

The activities that require prior consent from the Minister under Regulation 5 are:

1. Reclamation, including infilling (ARC 01)
2. Blasting, drilling, dredging or otherwise removing or disturbing fossils, rock, minerals, mud, sand, gravel or other sediment (ARC 03)
3. All activities relating to turf cutting and/or peat extraction (ARC 04)
4. Cutting, uprooting or otherwise removing plants (ARC 05)
5. Introduction, or re-introduction, of plants or animals not found in the area (ARC 06)
6. Construction or alteration of tracks, paths, roads, bridges, culverts or access routes (ARC 09)
7. Digging, ploughing, harrowing or otherwise disturbing soil or substrate (ARC 11)
8. Applying inorganic or organic fertiliser, including slurry and farmyard manure (ARC 12)
9. Applying lime (ARC 13)
10. Storage, burial, disposal or recovery of any materials (ARC 14)
11. Burning, topping, clearing scrub or rough vegetation or reseeding (ARC 15)
12. Application of pesticides, including herbicides (ARC 18)
13. Supplementary feeding of livestock (ARC 19)
14. Significant changes in livestock density (including introduction of grazing), changes in livestock type or grazing season, other than on established reseeded grassland (ARC 20)
15. Works on, or alterations to, the banks, bed or flow of a drain, watercourse or waterbody (ARC 24)
16. Drainage works including digging, deepening, widening or blocking a drain, watercourse or waterbody (ARC 25)
17. Water abstraction, sinking of boreholes and wells (ARC 27)
18. Felling of trees or removing timber, including dead wood (ARC 28)
19. Planting of trees or multi-annual bioenergy crops (ARC 29)
20. Developing or consenting to the development or operation of commercial recreational/visitor facilities or organised recreational activities (ARC 31)

Exemptions are provided for certain activities, including:

* Harvesting of cultivated crops
* Grazing or mowing
* Planting of crops on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land
* Digging, ploughing, harrowing or otherwise disturbing soil or substrate on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 50m from a river, stream, floodplain, wetland, lake, turlough or pond
* Applying inorganic or organic fertiliser, including slurry and farmyard manure, on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
* Applying lime on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
* Storage, burial, disposal or recovery of any materials on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
* Burning, topping, clearing scrub or rough vegetation or reseeding on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
* Application of pesticides, including herbicides,

Answer:
A person who carries out prohibited activities in the Special Area of Conservation without Ministerial consent under these Regulations may be subject to penalties and enforcement powers.

According to Regulation 5(1) of these Regulations, a person shall not carry out, cause or permit to be carried out or continue to carry out, or assist in carrying out, any activity specified in Schedule 4 within the Special Area of Conservation except with, and in accordance with, consent given by the Minister under Regulation 30 of the Regulations of 2011.

If a person fails to comply with this requirement, they may be liable for an offence under these Regulations. The specific penalties for this offence are not outlined in the provided passages, but it is likely that the penalties would be in line with those outlined in the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015.

In addition to penalties, a person affected by a decision to refuse to give consent, to attach or vary conditions or revoke a consent under Regulation 30 of the Regulations of 2011, in respect of an activity referred to in paragraph (1), may appeal the decision under Regulation 37(3) of the Regulations of 2011.

It is worth noting that there are certain exceptions to the requirement for Ministerial consent, as outlined in Regulation 5(2) of these Regulations. A person is not required to obtain consent from the Minister if their proposed activity or continued activity is one that requires consent or consents under one or more of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 or under the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015, and the activity is carried out with and in compliance with such consent or consents.

Similarly, a person is not required to obtain consent from the Minister if their proposed activity or continued activity is part of a project that has received consent under one or more of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 or under the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015, and the project or activity is carried out with and in compliance with a consent or consents given under the applicable statutes.

In conclusion, a person who carries out prohibited activities in the Special Area of Conservation without Ministerial consent under these Regulations may be subject to penalties and enforcement powers, including the possibility of an offence under these Regulations.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

This Order appoints 1 April 2023 as the date on which paragraphs (b) and (c) of 
section 5 of the Health Insurance (Amendment) Act 2021 come into operation. 
The amendment introduces a time limit on the period in which risk equalisation 
credits can be claimed by health insurers from the Risk Equalisation Fund. It sets 
out that claims cannot be made to the Health Insurance Authority if entitlement 
to claim (or part thereof) arose more than six years before the 31 March in the 
year prior to the date of making the claim.

1. (1) These Rules, which may be cited as the Rules of the Superior Courts 

(Interrogatories) 2024, shall come into operation on the 31st day of July 2024.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the changes introduced to the existing Rules of the Superior Courts are as follows:

1. **Amendments to the citation of the Rules**: The Rules of the Superior Courts have been amended to include the years 2025, 2024, 2023, 2022, 2021, and 2020 in their citation, indicating that these years have seen updates to the Rules.

2. **New provisions for service out of the jurisdiction**: The Rules have been updated to include new provisions for service out of the jurisdiction, as outlined in the passage starting with "1. Save as otherwise provided for in Orders 11A, 11B, 11C, 11D and 11E...". These provisions detail the circumstances under which the Court may allow service out of the jurisdiction, including cases involving land, contracts, torts, and more.

3. **Introduction of new rules**: The passages indicate the introduction of new rules, such as the Rules of the Superior Courts (Particulars) 2024, which came into operation on June 7, 2024, and the Rules of the Superior Courts (Interrogatories) 2024, which came into operation on July 31, 2024.

4. **Construal of the Rules**: The Rules of the Superior Courts are to be construed together with the Rules of the Superior Courts as amended by these new rules, as indicated in passages (2) of each of the new rules.

In summary, the changes introduced to the existing Rules of the Superior Courts include amendments to the citation of the Rules, new provisions for service out of the jurisdiction, the introduction of new rules, and the construal of the Rules together with the amended Rules of the Superior Courts.

Answer:
The purpose of inserting Appendix MM into the Rules of the Superior Courts is to provide a standardized form for the submission of Appellant Details, as outlined in the passage "1. Appellant Details" which is part of the forms set out in Appendix MM.

This form is intended to be used in conjunction with the Rules of the Superior Courts, specifically Order 129, which is amended by the insertion of "Appendix MM" in various places, as mentioned in passage 3.

The insertion of Appendix MM is part of a broader amendment to the Rules of the Superior Courts, which is aimed at providing clarity and consistency in the submission of information to the court. The specific details required in the Appellant Details form, such as the Appellant's full name, original status in the proceedings, and solicitor's details, are intended to facilitate efficient and effective processing of appeals.

In terms of the specific statutory instrument numbers, the insertion of Appendix MM is part of the Rules of the Superior Courts (No. 1)(Powers of Attorney Act 1996) 2000 (S.I. No. 66 of 2000), which is amended by the insertion of Regulation 4, as mentioned in passage 2.

The Rules of the Superior Courts as amended by these Rules may be cited as the Rules of the Superior Courts 1986 to 2023, as stated in passage 1 of the 2023 statutory instrument, and as the Rules of the Superior Courts 1986 to 2024, as stated in passage 1 of the 2024 statutory instruments.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the institutions required to pay a levy under these Regulations are:

1. Credit Institutions (Category A)
2. Insurance Undertakings (Category B)
3. Intermediaries and Debt Management Firms (Category C)
4. Investment Business Firms (Category D)
5. Credit Unions (Category F)
6. Moneylenders Approved by the Bank (Category G)
7. Approved Professional Bodies (Category H)
8. Bureaux de Change (Category J)
9. Financial service providers falling within Regulation 9(d) of these Regulations (Category L)
10. Retail Credit Firms, Home Reversion Firms, and Credit Servicing Firms (Category M)
11. Payment Institutions and E-Money Institutions (Category N)
12. Pawnbrokers (Category O)

The exemption that applies is for intermediaries who are members of the Society of the Irish Motor Industry (“SIMI”). The SIMI shall pay a flat rate levy of €12,000 for and on behalf of its members who are intermediaries as described in Category C, and such a payment will discharge those intermediaries’ obligation to pay a levy pursuant to these Regulations.

arising from derivative contracts as listed in Annex II to Regulation (EU) No

(8) The value assigned to liabilities arising from derivative contracts may 
not be less than 75% of the value of the same liabilities resulting from the 
application of the accounting provisions applicable to the Union branch or 
Limited Activity Investment Firm concerned for the purposes of financial 
reporting. 

(9) If, under national accounting standards applying to a Union branch or 
Limited Activity Investment Firm, there is no accounting measure of exposure 
for certain derivative instruments because those derivative instruments are held 
off-balance sheet, the Union branch or Limited Activity Investment Firm 
concerned shall report to the Bank the sum of the fair values of those 
derivatives, where the sum is negative, as the replacement cost and add those 
derivatives to its on-balance sheet accounting values. 

(10) For the purpose of this Regulation, the total liabilities referred to in 
paragraph (1) shall exclude the accounting value of liabilities arising from 
derivative contracts and include the corresponding value determined in 
accordance with paragraphs (7) to (9). 

(11) For verifying whether all conditions and requirements referred to in 
paragraphs (5) to (10) are met, the Bank shall be based on the relevant 
assessments conducted by competent authorities that are made available in 
accordance with Article 90 of the BRRD.

8. (1) The date by which the Bank shall notify each Union branch and 
Limited Activity Investment Firm of its decision determining the levy to be paid 
by them for the levy period 2022 shall be 1 May 2022. 

(2) The Bank shall notify the decision made in respect of each Union branch 

and Limited Activity Investment Firm in any of the following ways: 

(a) 

electronically or by other comparable means of communication 
allowing for an acknowledgment of receipt; 

 
 
 10 [190] 

(b) by registered mail with a form of acknowledgment of receipt. 

(3) The decision made in respect of each Union branch and Limited Activity 

Investment Firm shall specify – 

(a) 

(b) 

the condition and the means by which the levy shall be paid, and 

the share of irrevocable payment commitments referred to in 
Article 103 of Directive 2014/59/EU that each Union branch or 
Limited Activity Investment Firm can use. 

(4) For the purposes of paragraph (3), the Bank shall accept collateral only 
of the kind and under conditions that allow for swift realisability, including in 
the event of a resolution decision over the weekend, and the collateral should be 
conservatively valued to reflect significantly deteriorated market conditions. 

(5) The date by which each Limited Activity Investment Firm and Union 

branch is liable to pay the levy for the levy period 2022 shall be 3 June 2022. 

(6) Without prejudice to any other remedy available to the Bank, in the event 
of partial payment, non-payment or non-compliance with the requirement set out 
in the decision made in respect of each Union branch and Limited Activity 
Investment Firm, the Union branch or Limited Activity Firm concerned shall 
incur a daily penalty on the outstanding amount of the instalment. 

(7) The daily penalty interest shall accrue on a daily basis on the amount due 
at an interest rate applied by the European Central Bank to its principal 
refinancing operations, as published in the C series of the Official Journal of the 
European Union, in force on the first calendar day of the month in which the 
payment deadline falls, increased by 8 percentage points from the date on which 
the instalment was due.

Answer:
A person who commits an offence under these Regulations may be liable to various penalties depending on the specific regulation and the nature of the offence. 

According to Regulation 8(1), a person who commits an offence under Regulation 7(1) is liable on summary conviction to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months, or to both. 

Regulation 10 states that a person who commits an offence under these Regulations is liable— 

(a) on summary conviction to a Class A fine, or 

(b) on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €100,000. 

Regulation 44(1) states that a person who commits an offence under Regulations 19 or 28 is liable on conviction to a class A fine. 

Regulation 44(2) states that a person who commits an offence under Regulations 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16, 18, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 29, 30, 31, 32(3), 33(3), 33(6), 39, 40, or 42 is liable— 

(a) on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, or to both, or to a class A fine, or 

(b) on conviction on indictment to a fine not exceeding €250,000, or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, or to both. 

Regulation 44(3) states that a person who commits an offence under Regulation 32(1), (2), or (4) is liable— 

(a) on summary conviction, to— 

(i) a class A fine, 

(ii) imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, 

(iii) the forfeiture of any consideration or advantage obtained in connection with the offence or, in the alternative, the forfeiture of land, cash, or other property of an equivalent value to such consideration or advantage, or 

(iv) any combination of the penalties referred to in subparagraphs (i) to (iii), or 

(b) on conviction on indictment, to— 

(i) a fine not exceeding €500,000, 

(ii) imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, 

(iii) the forfeiture of any consideration or advantage obtained in connection with the offence or, in the alternative, the forfeiture of land, cash, or other property of an equivalent value to such consideration or advantage, or 

(iv) any combination of the penalties referred to in subparagraphs (i) to (iii). 

Regulation 49 states that a person who commits an offence under these Regulations is liable— 

(a) on summary conviction, to a class A fine, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or both, or 

(b) on conviction on indictment, to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or both. 

Regulation 15(1) states that a person who commits an offence under Regulation 14(9) is liable on summary conviction, to a class A fine. 

Regulation 15(2) states that a person who commits an offence under these Regulations (other than an offence referred to in paragraph (1)) is liable— 

(a) on summary conviction, to a class A fine, or 

(b) on conviction on indictment to a fine not exceeding €250,000. 

Regulation 32(1) states that a person who contravenes Regulation 21(1) or 10, 22(1) or 11, 23(1) or 11, 25(1) or 28(5) commits an offence.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures 
contained in Council Regulation (EU) No. 401/2013 of 2 May 2013 as 
amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Myanmar/Burma. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provide for appropriate 
penalties.

Answer:
The powers granted to competent authorities under these Regulations to ensure compliance with the EU sanctions on Myanmar/Burma include:

- Issuing directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions.
- Creating offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to implementation of the sanctions.
- Providing for appropriate penalties for breaches of the Council Regulations or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State.

These powers are granted under the Regulations to enforce the restrictive measures contained in Council Regulation (EU) No. 401/2013 of 2 May 2013 as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Myanmar/Burma.

Answer:
To determine the effective commencement date for the remaining provisions of the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 under this Order, we need to consider the various statutory instruments provided.

The CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 (Establishment Day) Order 2020 (No. 454 of 2020) appointed the 27th day of October 2020 as the establishment day for the purposes of the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019. This Order specified that the provisions of Part 1 and section 4 of the Act come into operation on the 21st day of October 2020, while the provisions of sections 5 to 10 of Chapter 1 of Part 2, Chapters 2, 3, 4, 6 and 7 of Part 2, and Part 3 of the Act come into operation on the 27th day of October 2020.

The CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 (Section 12(3A)) (Extension of Period for Making of Claims) Order 2022 (No. 240 of 2022) specified the 26th day of July 2022 as the date for the purposes of paragraphs (a)(ii) and (b) of subsection (1) of section 12 of the Act.

However, the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 (Establishment Day) Order 2020 (No. 454 of 2020) and the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 (Section 12(3A)) (Extension of Period for Making of Claims) Order 2022 (No. 240 of 2022) do not provide the effective commencement date for the remaining provisions of the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019.

The CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 (Commencement) Order 2022 (No. 75 of 2022) appointed the 23rd day of May 2022 as the day on which the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 (No. 31 of 2019) shall, in so far as it is not already in operation, come into operation. 

Therefore, the effective commencement date for the remaining provisions of the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 under this Order is the 23rd day of May 2022.

35. (1) A person may appeal a prohibition order served on him or her, to the 
Circuit Court in the circuit in which the order was served, not later than 7 days 
after the service of the notice or order concerned. 

(2) The bringing of an appeal under this Regulation against a prohibition 
which is to take effect immediately on service shall not have the effect of 
suspending the operation of the order, but the appellant may apply to the Circuit 
Court to have the operation of the order suspended until the appeal is disposed 
of and, on such application, the Court may, if it thinks it proper to do so, direct 
that the operation of the order be suspended until the appeal is disposed of. 

(3) The Circuit Court shall, upon an appeal under this Regulation, do one of 

the following:

The specific amendments made to the sitting schedule for the Letterkenny District Court under this Order are as follows:

- The First Schedule to the District Court (Areas) Order, 1961 (S.I. No. 5 of 1961) is amended by substituting the sitting days for the Letterkenny District Court with the following: 
  - First, Second, Third, and Fourth Monday in each month
  - First Tuesday in each month
  - First and Second Wednesday in each month
  - First, Third, and Fourth Thursday in each month
  - All sittings are held at 10.30am

- The Second Schedule to the District Court (Areas) Order, 1961 (S.I. No. 5 of 1961) is also amended in the same manner as the First Schedule.

These amendments apply to the Letterkenny District Court, and the order comes into operation on the 1st of July 2022.

Passage 2(1) further clarifies that, "Save where otherwise expressly provided by this Order: (a) in the event that any conflict shall arise between the provision of any rule of this Order and any other provision of these Rules, the provision of the rule of this Order shall, in respect of any proceedings entered in the Planning & Environment List, prevail, and (b) unless the context otherwise requires, any provision of these Rules not inconsistent with this Order shall apply to proceedings entered in the Planning & Environment List."

Passage 2(2) states: "This Order applies subject to any contrary provision in the 2000 Act, the 2024 Act or any enactment other than these Rules."

This passage suggests that the Order is subject to other enactments, which may affect its application to proceedings commenced before its commencement.

3. Other provisions of the Rules will still apply unless they are inconsistent with the Order (Passage 2(1)(b)).
4. The Order is subject to other enactments, which may affect its application (Passage 2(2)).

Therefore, the Order will affect proceedings already initiated before its commencement, but its application will be subject to other enactments and provisions of the Rules.

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to identify the specific categories of information that undertakings must provide under the Schedule to this Order for the purpose of the Business Expenditure on R&D Survey.

From the passages provided, we can see that the Schedule to this Order requires undertakings to provide information regarding the following categories:

1. The nature of its business activity insofar as it relates to R&D (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
2. Expenditure on in-house R&D activity (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
3. Estimated expenditure on in-house R&D activity (for the years 2020, 2022, and 2024).
4. Sources of funds for in-house R&D activity performed (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
5. Categories of in-house R&D activity performed and the expenditure on each category (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
6. The number of persons involved in in-house R&D activity, including their roles, qualifications, and gender, and the amount of time spent by each person on that activity (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
7. R&D activity at local unit level (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
8. Expenditure on R&D activity performed on behalf of the undertaking by other persons (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
9. Whether the undertaking is likely to increase the number of persons involved in in-house R&D activity, by reference to the qualifications of the persons concerned (for the periods 2020-2025, 2022-2027, and 2024-2029).
10. Engagement in joint R&D projects with other persons (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).

Therefore, the specific categories of information that undertakings must provide under the Schedule to this Order for the purpose of the Business Expenditure on R&D Survey are:

- The nature of its business activity insofar as it relates to R&D (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- Expenditure on in-house R&D activity (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- Estimated expenditure on in-house R&D activity (for the years 2020, 2022, and 2024).
- Sources of funds for in-house R&D activity performed (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- Categories of in-house R&D activity performed and the expenditure on each category (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- The number of persons involved in in-house R&D activity, including their roles, qualifications, and gender, and the amount of time spent by each person on that activity (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- R&D activity at local unit level (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- Expenditure on R&D activity performed on behalf of the undertaking by other persons (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).
- Whether the undertaking is likely to increase the number of persons involved in in-house R&D activity, by reference to the qualifications of the persons concerned (for the periods 2020-2025, 2022-2027, and 2024-2029).
- Engagement in joint R&D projects with other persons (for the years 2019, 2021, and 2023).

Medical lenses

2. The Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) 
Regulations 2007 (S.I. No. 142 of 2007) are amended by the insertion of the 
following article after article 110A: 

“Medical lenses 

110B. A person shall be entitled to medical appliance benefit in relation

frequency as may, from time to time, be fixed by the Minister.”. 

GIVEN under my Official Seal,

HEATHER HUMPHREYS,

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Currently, article 105(2) of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments 
and Control) Regulations 2007 provides that dental, optical or medical 
appliance treatment benefits covered by the Treatment Benefit Scheme, can be 
obtained in another Member State and the amount which would have been 
payable, as the case may be, to the audiologist, dentist, dispensing optician, 
ophthalmologist or optometrist -if the treatment was obtained in this State- will 
be payable to the claimant. 

After the United Kingdom withdraws from the European Union, the effect of 
these Regulations will be to preserve the current position whereby a person 
who receives eligible treatment in the United Kingdom, continues to be entitled 
to receive the amount payable for the same treatment in this State.

Answer:
There is no passage that directly addresses the entitlement regarding the provision of medical lenses under the Treatment Benefit scheme. However, passage 2 mentions the insertion of article 110B, which states that a person shall be entitled to medical appliance benefit in relation to the provision of medical lenses once in every two years, or such other frequency as may, from time to time, be fixed by the Minister.

Based on this information, the entitlement conferred by Regulation 2 regarding the provision of medical lenses under the Treatment Benefit scheme is that a person is entitled to medical appliance benefit for the provision of medical lenses once in every two years, or as may be fixed by the Minister.

Based on the provided passages, the stated purposes of these Regulations are as follows:

1. To ensure the UCITS Regulations are in alignment with EU requirements. (S.I. number not specified)
2. To amend the Planning and Development Regulations, 2001. (S.I. number not specified)
3. To amend the definition of a competent authority to include authorised persons in the United Kingdom up to 30 June. (S.I. number not specified)
4. To substitute Schedules 1, 2, and 3 to S.I. No. 347 of 2013 - Commercial Vehicle Roadworthiness (Vehicle Testing) (No. 2) Regulations. (S.I. number not specified)
5. To replace Schedule 1 in the Misuse of Drugs (Prescription and Control of Supply of Cannabis for Medical Use) Regulations 2019 to list certain cannabis products or preparations for medical use as “specified controlled drugs”. (S.I. number: Misuse of Drugs (Prescription and Control of Supply of Cannabis for Medical Use) (Amendment) Regulations)
6. To update and replace the current Schedule 1, in the Misuse of Drugs (Prescription and Control of Supply of Cannabis for Medical Use) Regulations 2019 (as amended) (“the Principal Regulations”), in order to include additional cannabis products or preparations for medical use as “specified controlled drugs”. (S.I. number: Misuse of Drugs (Prescription and Control of Supply of Cannabis for Medical Use) (Amendment) Regulations)
7. To enable certain applications to be filed electronically on the Building Control Management System. (S.I. number not specified)

Note that the S.I. numbers are not specified for all the purposes mentioned above.

Answer:
The Minister who signed the Order bringing parts of the Circular Economy and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 2022 into effect is Eamon Ryan, Minister for the Environment, Climate and Communications.

Specifically, the Order that brought certain provisions of the Act into effect was the Circular Economy and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 2022 (Commencement of Certain Provisions) Order 2022, which was signed by Eamon Ryan on 22 August 2022. This Order appointed the 23rd day of August 2022 as the day on which Part 1, other than section 5, and Part 6 of the Act would come into operation.

Additionally, another Order, the Circular Economy and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 2022 (Commencement of Certain Provisions) Order 2023, was signed by Eamon Ryan on 21 December 2023, which revoked the Regulations of 2023 and provided for the continuation of certain rights and obligations.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the ministerial consents recorded for the making of these Regulations are as follows:

- The Minister may make regulations with the consent of the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform (Regulation 8(1) and (4)).
- The Minister may give directions with regard to any matter referred to in these Regulations (Regulation 4(1)).
- A person shall not carry out, cause or permit to be carried out or continue to carry out, or assist in carrying out, any activity specified in Schedule 4 within the Special Protection Area except with, and in accordance with, consent given by the Minister under Regulation 30 of the Regulations of 2011 (Regulation 5(1)).

However, there are certain exceptions to the requirement for consent, including:

- Activities that require consent or consents under one or more of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 or under the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015 (Regulation 5(2)(a) and (b)).
- Projects that have received consent under one or more of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 or under the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015 (Regulation 5(2)(b)).
- Projects that have received consent under one or more regulations made under the European Communities Act 1972 or under one or more regulations made under any of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 (Regulation 5(2)(c)).
- Activities that have been authorised as part of an agreed farm or land management plan (Regulation 5(2)(d)).

Therefore, the ministerial consents recorded for the making of these Regulations include the consent of the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, as well as the consent of the Minister under Regulation 30 of the Regulations of 2011, subject to certain exceptions.

Answer:
The Minister has the power to approve persons manufacturing or supplying bovine identification devices under Regulation 9 of the Bovines Identification Regulations 2022. 

Specifically, Regulation 9(1) states that the persons approved for the purposes of these Regulations to manufacture, sell and supply conventional ear-tags and electronic identification devices are mentioned in the Schedule. 

However, Regulation 9(2) also gives the Minister the power to grant an approval for the purposes of these Regulations in respect of the manufacture, sale and supply of a type of conventional ear-tag or electronic identification device that incorporates an electronic identifier bearing the identification code of a bovine within the meaning of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/2035 of 28 June 2019. 

The Minister may also attach conditions to an approval under this Regulation, vary or revoke a condition, or attach a new condition, under Regulation 9(3). The conditions may relate to various matters, including the provision of documents relating to bovines, technical standards relating to means of identification, security of means of identification, equipment, records and information, and tag loss rate. 

The Minister may refuse an application or suspend or revoke an approval under this Regulation if, in his or her opinion, the applicant or person to whom the approval is granted has been convicted of an offence, has failed to comply with a condition of an approval, has not furnished information required, or has furnished false or misleading information, under Regulation 9(7). 

The Minister must notify the applicant or person to whom the approval is granted of the proposal and the reason for the proposal, and give them the opportunity to make representations in relation to the proposal, under Regulation 9(8).

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Entitlement to payment of Jobseeker’s Benefit (JB) and Jobseeker’s Benefit 
(Self-Employed) (JBSE) 
is primarily determined by a person’s PRSI 
contribution record and earnings in the relevant Governing Contribution Year 
(GCY). For new claims made in 2023, the GCY is 2021. Similar arrangements 
apply to Illness Benefit (IB). 

As respects the contribution condition, the Social Welfare (Covid-19) 
(Amendment) Act 2020 provided that a person entitled to and in receipt of 
Pandemic Unemployment Payment (PUP) or Jobseeker’s payment who had an 
underlying entitlement to PUP would be deemed to have made an employment 
contribution for each entitlement period the customer was in receipt of these 
payments. 

The rate of payment of JB, JBSE and IB is determined by the person's average 
reckonable weekly earnings or income in the GCY. For the full rate to be paid, 
the earnings in the GCY divided by the number of qualifying contributions in 
that year must be above the statutory amount of €300. 

As respects earnings, those in receipt of PUP in 2021 (GCY for 2023 claims), 
and who do not have any actual earnings and related paid contributions in 
2021, will not have the required €300 average earnings. These Regulations 
provide that a recipient in this position will be considered to have satisfied the 
condition to have the required €300 average earnings, and will be entitled to 
payment at the maximum rate. However, in cases where there are actual 
earnings and related paid contributions in the GCY, the standard calculation of 
earnings divided by paid contributions will apply. 

These Regulations apply to the exceptional circumstances which applied in 
2020 and 2021 to provide that a person who was in receipt of PUP during the 
governing contribution years of 2020 or 2021 is regarded as satisfying the 
GCY earnings requirement for those years.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, there is no Regulation 2 that introduces an amendment regarding the attribution of self-employment contributions for the 2021 contribution year. 

However, the passages do provide information on the amendments made to the Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) Regulations 1996. 

The Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) (Amendment) (No. 2) (Attribution of self-employment contributions) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 730 of 2021) inserted a new article 27 into the Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) Regulations 1996, which provided that a self-employed contributor entitled to and in receipt of the Covid-19 pandemic unemployment payment, or a jobseeker’s payment (who would otherwise be entitled to the Covid-19 pandemic unemployment payment), was deemed to have made 52 self-employment contributions in the 2020 contribution year.

The Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) (Amendment) (No. 2) (Attribution of self-employment contributions) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 747 of 2022) amended article 27 of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) Regulations 1996 to provide that a self-employed contributor shall be deemed to have made 52 self-employment contributions in the 2021 contribution year, where the same circumstances apply.

Therefore, the amendment introduced by the Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) (Amendment) (No. 2) (Attribution of self-employment contributions) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 747 of 2022) regarding the attribution of self-employment contributions for the 2021 contribution year is that a self-employed contributor shall be deemed to have made 52 self-employment contributions in the 2021 contribution year, where the same circumstances apply.

10. Where a person wishes to purchase a copyright licence from Tailte 
Éireann, the fee specified in column 3 of Part 6 of Schedule 2 shall be payable 
to Tailte Éireann in respect of the copyright licence specified in column 2 of 
that Part opposite that fee so specified.
Answer:
To answer the question, we need to refer to the passages provided. The question asks about the categories of licences and digital models defined under Regulation 2 of this Order for the purposes of Tailte Éireann's geospatial operations.

From the passages, we can identify the following categories of licences and digital models:

1. **Copyright Licence**: This is a licence granted by Tailte Éireann to produce a copy of a product, specified in Part 1 or 3 of Schedule 2, for a specified purpose.
2. **Data Licence Agreement**: This is a licence for the use, distribution, and access of one or more data sets specified in column 2 of Schedule 3.
3. **Digital Cartographic Model (DCM)**: This is a digital representation of the national map where the data is supplied in raster format after cartographic design has been applied. The DCM is further categorized into:
	* **DCM Core**: Full country coverage.
	* **DCM Local**: Full country coverage.
	* **DCM Regional**: Country coverage.
	* **DCM National**: Country coverage.
4. **Digital Landscape Model (DLM)**: This is a digital representation of the national map, at different resolutions, where the data is supplied in vector format with no cartographic design applied.
5. **Digital Terrain Model (DTM)**: This is a 3-dimensional digital representation of a terrain surface.
6. **Previous Map Revision**: This is a certified archive map that represents the typography of an area at a particular point in time.

Additionally, the passages mention the following categories related to geospatial operations:

1. **PLACE Data**: This is an extract of topographic data that is readily available for any location within the State.
2. **PLACE Map**: This is a topographic map that is readily available for any location within the State.
3. **GIS**: This is a Geographic Information System that is designed to capture, store, manipulate, analyze, and present geospatial or geographic data.
4. **Royalty Fee**: This is a fee that is payable to Tailte Éireann for the publication of specified Tailte Éireann data.

Therefore, the categories of licences and digital models defined under Regulation 2 of this Order for the purposes of Tailte Éireann's geospatial operations are:

* Copyright Licence
* Data Licence Agreement
* Digital Cartographic Model (DCM)
* Digital Landscape Model (DLM)
* Digital Terrain Model (DTM)
* Previous Map Revision
* PLACE Data
* PLACE Map
* GIS
* Royalty Fee

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the enforcement powers of competent authorities under these Regulations to ensure compliance with EU sanctions concerning Iraq are as follows:

Competent authorities of the State may issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions contained in Council Regulation (EU) No. 1210/2003 of 7 July 2003, as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Iraq.

These directions are intended to ensure compliance with the EU sanctions, and competent authorities have the power to issue them to give full effect to the sanctions.

In addition to issuing directions, the Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulation or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to implementation of the sanctions.

These offences are punishable by appropriate penalties, which are not specified in the provided passages but are presumably outlined in the Regulations themselves.

Therefore, the enforcement powers of competent authorities under these Regulations include the ability to issue directions and to create offences for non-compliance, with penalties to be applied as necessary.

According to Schedule 2, the following provisions of the Council Regulation are subject to penalties:

However, the passages do not explicitly state the corresponding penalties for these offences. To determine the penalties, we need to refer to the relevant regulations or statutory instruments that are not provided in the given passages.

Assuming that the penalties are specified in the Council Implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/1779, which is mentioned in Passage 5, we can infer that the penalties for breaches of the Council Regulation are established in this regulation.

 4 [129]

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Currently, a child who would otherwise be eligible for Domiciliary Care 
Allowance but who remains in care in hospital after birth due to illness or 
disability is not eligible for Domiciliary Care Allowance, and the child’s carer 
is not eligible, as the case may be, for Carer’s Benefit, Carer’s Allowance, and 
the Carer’s Support Grant. 

However, where Domiciliary Care Allowance is already in payment for a 
qualified child before that child enters hospital for the purpose of receiving 
temporary medical or other treatment, Domiciliary Care Allowance continues 
to be payable for not more than 26 weeks in a twelve-month period. In such 
circumstances, the carer of the child is eligible, as the case may be, for Carer’s 
Benefit, Carer’s Allowance, and the Carer’s Support Grant. 

Budget 23 provided that in respect of a child (otherwise eligible for domiciliary 
care allowance) who remains in hospital immediately after birth for medical 
treatment, Domiciliary Care Allowance will be payable for up to 26 weeks in a 
twelve-month period. 

These Regulations amend the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments 
and Control) Regulations 2007 to provide that in circumstances where a child 
(otherwise eligible for domiciliary care allowance) remains in hospital 
immediately after birth for medical treatment, the carer of the child is eligible, 
as the case may be, for Carer’s Benefit, Carer’s Allowance, and the Carer’s 
Support Grant. 

These Regulations have effect from 1 January 2023.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Currently, children who remain in care in hospital after birth due to illness or 
disability are ineligible for Domiciliary Care Allowance. 

However, where Domiciliary Care Allowance is already in payment for a child 
before that child enters hospital for the purpose of receiving temporary medical 
or other treatment, Domiciliary Care Allowance continues to be payable for up 
to 26 weeks in a twelve-month period. 

Budget 23 provides that in respect of a child (otherwise eligible for domiciliary 
care allowance) who remains in hospital immediately after birth for medical 
treatment, Domiciliary Care Allowance will be payable for up to 26 weeks in a 
twelve-month period. These Regulations provide for such cases where the child 
is born on or after 1 January 2023.

Answer:
Regulation 140E provides for continued payment of Domiciliary Care Allowance when a qualified child resides in an institution in the following specific circumstances:

1. Where the qualified child remains in hospital immediately after birth for medical treatment, and the child is born on or after 1 January 2023, Domiciliary Care Allowance is payable for up to 26 weeks in a 12-month period.

2. Where the qualified child is admitted to an institution on a full-time basis for the purpose of receiving medical or other treatment of a temporary nature, Domiciliary Care Allowance is payable for up to 26 weeks in a 12-month period.

In both cases, the carer of the child is eligible, as the case may be, for Carer's Benefit, Carer's Allowance, and the Carer's Support Grant.

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Currently, children who remain in care in hospital after birth due to illness or 
disability are ineligible for Domiciliary Care Allowance. 

However, where Domiciliary Care Allowance is already in payment for a child 
before that child enters hospital for the purpose of receiving temporary medical 
or other treatment, Domiciliary Care Allowance continues to be payable for up 
to 26 weeks in a twelve-month period. 

Budget 23 provides that in respect of a child (otherwise eligible for domiciliary 
care allowance) who remains in hospital immediately after birth for medical 
treatment, Domiciliary Care Allowance will be payable for up to 26 weeks in a 
twelve-month period. These Regulations provide for such cases where the child 
is born on or after 1 January 2023.

Answer:
A legal amendment does not appear to be introduced by Regulation 3(a) regarding the definition of normal residence for the purposes of Domiciliary Care Allowance eligibility. 

However, Regulation 3(a) amends article 140C of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) Regulations 2007 to insert a new sub-article (5) that states: 

"(5) Notwithstanding any other provision in this Chapter or the Act, where article 140E applies, a qualified child shall be regarded as normally residing with the qualified person, and the qualified person shall be regarded as providing for the care of the child." 

This amendment appears to clarify the circumstances under which a qualified child is considered to be normally residing with a qualified person, and when the qualified person is regarded as providing for the care of the child. 

It is worth noting that article 140E is also amended by Regulation 3(b), which substitutes a new article for the existing one. However, the text of the new article 140E is not provided in the passages, so it is unclear what specific changes are made to this article. 

In any case, Regulation 3(a) does not appear to introduce a new definition of normal residence for the purposes of Domiciliary Care Allowance eligibility.

Answer:
These Regulations modify the treatment of income from renting out a room under the Social Welfare framework by disregarding a certain amount of income received from renting out a room in a person's home to a person who is not an employee or an immediate family member.

The maximum amount of income that can be disregarded is €269.23 per week, which equates to €14,000 per annum. This disregard applies to the assessment of means for the purposes of weekly social assistance payments, increases for qualified adults, and the Working Family Payment.

The duration of the disregard has been extended several times. Initially, the disregard was to cease with effect from 17 March 2023 (Social Welfare (Consolidated Supplementary Welfare Allowance) (Amendment) (No. 3) (Calculation of Means) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 396 of 2022)). However, this was extended to 17 March 2025 (Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) (Amendment) (No. 10) (Income Disregard) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 397 of 2022)). Further, the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) (Amendment) (No. 4) (Income Disregard) Regulations 2023 extended the duration of the disregard until 17 March 2027.

The definition of "home" in article 3 has been amended to extend the definition to include the residence of a person who moves out of their home under the Nursing Homes Support Scheme (alternatively known as Fair Deal), from 1 February 2024, and the residence of a Local Authority tenant who rents out a room to a student under the "Room for a Student – Local Authority Scheme", from 1 December 2023.

Answer:
To determine which provisions of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) Regulations 2007 are amended and what specific date governs the cessation of the income disregard, we need to identify the relevant passages.

A person installing a reverse vending machine under Class 42A must meet the following specific planning and safety conditions:

- The opening of the reverse vending machine must be located on an inner wall of the shop.
- The storage unit and associated roofed area must be developed to the outside of the shop.
- The reverse vending machine, together with the storage unit and associated roofed area, must operate ancillary to the shop.

Based on the provided passages, the following offences and penalties are created under Regulation 6 of these Regulations:

- A person who carries out, causes or permits to be carried out, or assists in the carrying out of an activity referred to in Regulation 5(1), without a consent or otherwise than in accordance with a consent given by the Minister under Regulation 30 of the Regulations of 2011, commits an offence.

The penalties for this offence are:

- On summary conviction, a class A fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, or both.
- On conviction on indictment, a fine not exceeding €500,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, or both.

The court shall, in particular, have regard to the risk or extent of injury to the environment arising from the act constituting the offence when imposing a penalty.

Proceedings for this offence may be brought summarily by:

- The Minister
- The public authority concerned
- A member of the Garda Síochána, in accordance with section 8 of the Garda Síochána Act 2005

Any fine in respect of an offence prosecuted summarily by a public authority shall be paid to that public authority.

In the case of a body corporate, the penalties are:

- On summary conviction, a class A fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months, or to both.

It is worth noting that there are multiple passages with the same content, but they all describe the same offences and penalties.

4. (1) The Council shall appoint persons of competence and integrity to act 
as a Returning Officer and a substitute returning officer, who shall act in the 
event that the Returning Officer is unable or unavailable to act, for the purpose 
of each Election. 

(2) In this bye-law, any reference to the Returning Officer in relation to any 
act, matter or function for which a Returning Officer is appointed by or under 
this bye-law shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be interpreted as 
including a reference to the substitute returning officer. 

(3) The Returning Officer will ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither 
he or she, nor any person employed by him or her, has any conflict of interest, 
and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the 
Election. Should a conflict of interest arise, in relation to the Returning Officer, 
he or she will immediately notify the Council and the substitute Returning 
Officer will take over the running of the Election. In the case of a conflict arising 
with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee’s 
involvement in the Election. 

 
 
 
 [253] 5 

(4) The Council and/or the Registration Board shall provide the Returning 
Officer with all information which the Returning Officer deems necessary for 
the purposes of conducting the Election. 

(5) The Returning Officer may, if he or she considers it necessary for the 
performance of his or her duties, and with the consent of Council, appoint such 
person or persons as he or she considers fit and proper to assist him or her. 

(6) The Returning Officer or any person appointed by him or her for any 
purpose relating to the Election shall not be a Candidate or an agent of a

is or has been a Candidate,

is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election.

event that the Returning Officer is unable or unavailable to act, for the purpose 
of each Election. 

(2) In this bye-law, any reference to the Returning Officer in relation to any 
act, matter or function for which a Returning Officer is appointed by or under 
this bye-law shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be interpreted as 
including a reference to the substitute returning officer. 

(3) The Returning Officer will ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither 
he or she, nor any person employed by him or her, has any conflict of interest, 
and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the 
Election. Should a conflict of interest arise, in relation to the Returning Officer, 
he or she will immediately notify the Council and the substitute Returning 
Officer will take over the running of the Election. In the case of a conflict arising 
with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee’s 
involvement in the Election. 

 
 
 
 4 [358] 

(4) The Council and/or the Registration Board shall provide the Returning 
Officer with all information which the Returning Officer deems necessary for 
the purposes of conducting the Election. 

(5) The Returning Officer may, if he or she considers it necessary for the 
performance of his or her duties, and with the consent of the Council, appoint 
such person or persons as he or she considers fit and proper to assist him or her. 

(6) The Returning Officer or any person appointed by him or her for any 
purpose relating to the Election shall not be a Candidate or a Relative of a 
Candidate at that Election or associated in furthering the candidature of any 
Candidate at that Election.

is or has been a Candidate,

or 

(c) 

is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election.

Powers and functions of Returning Officer
Answer:
The authority responsible for appointing the Returning Officer is the Council, as stated in passages 4.1, 5.1, and others.

To manage conflicts of interest during the election process, the Returning Officer must ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither they nor any person employed by them has any conflict of interest, and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the Election (passage 3). If a conflict of interest arises, the Returning Officer must immediately notify the Council, and the substitute Returning Officer will take over the running of the Election (passage 3).

In the case of a conflict arising with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee's involvement in the Election (passage 3). The Returning Officer shall not appoint for any purpose relating to the Election a person who to the knowledge of the Returning Officer – is or has been a Candidate, has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate, or is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election (passage 7).

Therefore, to manage conflicts of interest during the election process, the Returning Officer must:

1. Ensure that they and their employees do not have any conflicts of interest.
2. Avoid any perceived conflicts of interest.
3. Notify the Council immediately if a conflict of interest arises.
4. Discontinue the involvement of any employee with a conflict of interest.
5. Not appoint any person who is or has been a Candidate, has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate, or is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election.

5. (1) Subject to the provisions of this bye-law, the Returning Officer shall 
be responsible for determining all questions of procedure, form, or manner in 
which the Election shall take place and shall have the duty to ensure the validity 
and integrity of the nomination and Election processes. He or she shall have all 
powers necessary to carry out such functions, responsibility and duty, and 
without prejudice to the generality thereof, shall have the power to make 
decisions with regard to the qualification or disqualification of candidates, the 
making of decisions in respect of valid or invalid votes, the conduct of the count, 
and all other matters which might arise during the course of the Election. 

(2) The Returning Officer shall determine the form and content of all 
nomination papers, ballots, declarations, instructions, advertisements and 
notices required to be issued in accordance with this bye-law. 

(3) The Returning Officer will set the date for establishing the Electoral 
register, the closing date for receipt of nominations, the date for the opening of 
the poll and the closing date for receipt of ballots and shall have power to adjust 
or revise such dates, should the Returning Officer deem fit in any particular 
circumstances. 

(4) The Returning Officer shall keep or cause to be kept appropriate records 

in connection with the Election. 

(5) The decision of the Returning Officer on any matters arising in respect 
of the conduct of the Election or otherwise in connection with any Election is 
final.

6. (1) Subject to the provisions of this bye-law, the Returning Officer shall 
be responsible for determining all questions of procedure, form, or manner in 
which the Election shall take place and shall have the duty to ensure the validity 
and integrity of the nomination and Election processes. He or she shall have all 
powers necessary to carry out such functions, responsibility and duty, and 
without prejudice to the generality thereof, shall have the power to make 
decisions with regard to the qualification or disqualification of candidates, the 
making of decisions in respect of valid or invalid votes, the conduct of the count, 
and all other matters which might arise during the course of the Election. 

(2) The Returning Officer shall determine the form and content of all 
nomination papers, ballots, declarations, instructions, advertisements and 
notices required to be issued in accordance with this bye-law. 

(3) The Returning Officer will set the date for establishing the Electoral 
register, the closing date for receipt of nominations, the date for the opening of 
the poll and the closing date for receipt of ballots and shall have power to adjust 
or revise such dates, should the Returning Officer deem fit in any particular 
circumstances. 

(4) The Returning Officer shall keep or cause to be kept appropriate records 

in connection with the Election. 

(5) The decision of the Returning Officer on any matters arising in respect 
of the conduct of the Election or otherwise in connection with any Election is 
final. 

 
 
 
 [198] 5 

Scrutineers
Answer:
The procedural powers granted to the Returning Officer under Regulation 5 to ensure the validity and integrity of the election process include:

- Determining all questions of procedure, form, or manner in which the Election shall take place.
- Ensuring the validity and integrity of the nomination and Election processes.
- Having all powers necessary to carry out such functions, responsibility, and duty.
- Making decisions with regard to the qualification or disqualification of candidates.
- Making decisions in respect of valid, invalid, or spoiled votes.
- Conducting counts and transferring votes.
- Determining the form and content of all nomination papers, ballot papers, declarations, instructions, advertisements, and notices required to be issued in accordance with this bye-law.
- Setting the date for establishing the Electoral register, the closing date for receipt of nominations, the date for the opening of the poll, and the closing date for receipt of ballot papers.
- Adjusting or revising such dates, should the Returning Officer deem fit in any particular circumstances.
- Determining the official mark to be used for the purpose of marking ballot papers.
- Keeping or causing to be kept appropriate records in connection with the Election.
- Making decisions on any matters arising in respect of the conduct of the Election or otherwise in connection with any Election.

These powers are outlined in Regulation 5, and the Returning Officer has the duty to ensure the validity and integrity of the nomination and Election processes.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations are made under section 4(4A) of the Planning and 
Development Act 2000, as amended. 

In areas other than a city, a town or other specified areas, the replacement of 
broadleaf high forest by conifer species in areas less than 10 hectares is 
exempted development under Article 6(3) of the Planning and Development 
Regulations 2001. Under section 4(4) of the Planning and Development Act 
2000, this development is no longer exempted if it would require an 
environmental impact assessment and/or an appropriate assessment. 

Article 3 of these Regulations amends the Planning and Development 
Regulations, 2001, as amended, in accordance with section 4(4A) of the Act, 
by inserting a new Article 8H to ensure that this development remains 
exempted development, even where an environmental impact assessment 
and/or an appropriate assessment is required in cases where the development is 
licenced or approved by the Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine 
under section 6 of the Forestry Act, 2014.

Answer:
Under the Forestry (Amendment) Regulations 2023, when an environmental impact assessment is deemed unnecessary, the following new publication and appeal procedures are introduced:

1. The Minister shall publish the determination that an environmental impact assessment is not required, together with:
   - The main reasons for not requiring such an assessment, with reference to the criteria listed in Schedule 3.
   - Where proposed by the developer, any features of the project and measures envisaged to avoid or prevent what might otherwise have been significant adverse effects on the environment.

2. A determination under this regulation that an environmental impact assessment is not required may be appealed to the Forestry Appeals Committee in accordance with section 14A(4) of the Agriculture Appeals Act 2001 as part of the grounds of appeal upon which an appeal is made in respect of the licencing decision concerned.

3. An application to the High Court to review a decision in accordance with this section shall only be made where an applicant has first exercised their right to appeal a decision to the Forestry Appeals Committee in accordance with section 14A(4) of the Agriculture Appeals Act 2001.

Answer:
The new powers granted to the High Court under the amended Order 19 Rules 27 and 28 of the Rules of the Superior Courts are as follows:

The High Court may now order to be struck out or amended any matter in any indorsement or pleading which is unnecessary or which amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court, or which may unreasonably prejudice or delay the fair trial of the action. The Court may also, if it thinks fit, order the costs of the application to be paid as between solicitor and client.

These new powers are granted under the amended Order 19 Rules 27 and 28, which provide for the High Court's power to strike out or amend any matter in any indorsement or pleading that is unnecessary or amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court. This power is intended to enable the High Court to manage its cases more efficiently and to prevent unnecessary delays or costs.

The specific regulations and statutory instrument numbers that support these new powers are:

* Order 19 Rules 27 and 28 of the Rules of the Superior Courts, as amended by the Rules of the Superior Courts (Order 19) 2023.
* The Rules of the Superior Courts 1986 to 2023, as amended by the Rules of the Superior Courts (Order 19) 2023.

It is worth noting that these new powers are subject to the general principles of the Rules of the Superior Courts and the Constitution of Ireland, and must be exercised in accordance with the generally recognised principles of international law.

Answer:
When applying for a search warrant under the District Court (Companies Act 2014: Search Warrants) Rules 2023, a designated officer must provide the following information:

1. The designated officer must be a designated officer within the meaning of section 787(13) of the Companies Act 2014, designated by the Corporate Enforcement Authority for the purposes of the said Act and duly authorised by the said Authority.
2. The designated officer must have reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is material information within the meaning of section 787 of the said Act on the premises to be searched.
3. The designated officer must specify the material information that is suspected to be on the premises, which may include:
   - Books or documents of which production has been required under section [insert section] of the Companies Act 2014 on a specific date and which have not been produced in compliance with that requirement.
   - Books, documents, or other things (including a computer) that may provide evidence of or be related to the commission of an offence under the Companies Act 2014.
4. The designated officer must provide the basis for their belief that the material information is on the premises.
5. The designated officer must apply for the issue of a search warrant under section 787 of the Companies Act 2014 in respect of the said premises.

The search warrant, if issued, will authorise the designated officer to:
- Enter the premises, if necessary by force, and search the premises.
- Require any person found on the premises to give their name, home address, and occupation.
- Produce to the officer any material information that is in the custody or possession of that person.
- Seize and retain any material information found on the premises or in the custody or possession of any person found on the premises.
- Take any other steps that appear to the designated officer to be necessary for preserving or preventing interference with material information.

78. (1) Any person wishing to require the attendance of the Official 
Assignee or any other officer serving in the office of the Official Assignee at any 
court or place to give evidence in their official capacity or to produce any records 
in their custody, shall first apply to the Judge for liberty to do so. Where the 
Judge permits the attendance of any such officer to give evidence or to produce 
records, that officer shall be entitled to require that the person desiring his 
attendance shall deposit with him a sufficient sum of money to answer his just 
fees, charges and expenses, in respect of such attendance, and undertake to pay 
any further just fees, charges and expenses which may not be fully answered by 
such deposit. 

(2) A summons to a bankrupt or any other person under section 21 of the Act 

to attend before the Court shall be in the Form No 39. 

(3) A warrant for the arrest of an absconding bankrupt under section 23 of 

the Act and for his production before the Court shall be in the Form No 40. 

(4) A warrant for the arrest of a bankrupt or any other person under section 

23(2) or (3) of the Act shall be in the Form No 41. 

(5) A warrant of committal under section 24 of the Act shall be in the Form 

No 42, Form No 43 or Form No 44 as the case may be. 

(6) A warrant to direct the production of a bankrupt or any other person 

before the Court under section 25 of the Act shall be in the Form No 45. 

(7) A warrant of seizure issued under section 27 of the Act shall be in the 

Form No 46. 

(8) A search warrant issued under section 28 of the Act shall be in the Form 

No 47. 

XVI. Execution
Answer:
A designated officer under the search warrant form issued pursuant to section 787 of the Companies Act 2014 has the following enforcement powers:

1. **To enter the premises**: The designated officer is authorized to enter the premises at any time or times within 30 days after the date of the warrant, if necessary by force.
2. **To search the premises**: The designated officer is authorized to search the premises for material information within the meaning of section 787 of the Act.
3. **To require a person to give their name, home address, and occupation**: The designated officer is authorized to require any person found on the premises to provide their name, home address, and occupation.
4. **To produce material information**: The designated officer is authorized to require any person found on the premises to produce any material information that is in their custody or possession.
5. **To seize and retain material information**: The designated officer is authorized to seize and retain any material information found on the premises or in the custody or possession of any person found on the premises.
6. **To take other necessary steps**: The designated officer is authorized to take any other steps that appear necessary for preserving or preventing interference with material information.

These enforcement powers are conferred on designated officers under the search warrant form issued pursuant to section 787 of the Companies Act 2014, as outlined in Schedule No. 34.16.

From the passages provided, we can see that the Private Security Services Act 2004 (No. 12 of 2004) is the Principal Act, and it is amended by the Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2011 and the Private Security Services (Amendment) Act 2021.

However, there is no direct passage that explicitly states the statutory authority for the Minister to issue the Commencement Order. But, we can infer that the Minister is empowered to issue the Commencement Order under the Private Security Services Act 2004, as amended.

Therefore, the statutory authority that empowers the Minister to issue the Commencement Order bringing section 37 of the Private Security Services Act 2004 into operation is the Private Security Services Act 2004, as amended by the Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2011 and the Private Security Services (Amendment) Act 2021.

Answer:
The new forms of service and evidentiary certification permitted for the delivery of the Book of Evidence by these Rules are:

1. Electronic service of documents, including the Book of Evidence, by consent of the parties.
2. The Bankers' Books Evidence Acts 1879 to 1989 continue to apply with respect to any books of the transferor transferred to the transferee in connection with the assets, liabilities, or other matters, and to entries made in those books before the Transfer Date, as if such books were the books of the transferee.
3. Any book referred to in subparagraph (a) shall, on being proved to be in the custody of the transferee, be deemed to be one of the ordinary books of the transferee, and any entry therein purporting to have been made before the Transfer Date shall be deemed to have been made in the ordinary course of business.

These new forms of service and evidentiary certification are permitted under the District Court (Service of Book of Evidence) Rules 2023, which came into operation on the 24th day of November 2023.

Answer:
The specific amendment to the Principal Regulations regarding the inclusion of the Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 COVID-19 vaccine is made to the Eighth Schedule and the Twelfth Schedule to the Principal Regulations.

Regulation 3 of the Regulations of 2023 amends the Eighth Schedule by inserting the following entry:

- Medicinal Product: Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 dispersion for injection COVID-19 Vaccine (recombinant, adjuvanted)
- Route of administration: Dispersion for injection
- Form and presentation of product administered: Intramuscular injection
- Indication for which the medicinal product may be administered: Active immunisation to prevent COVID-19 caused by SARS-CoV-2 in individuals 12 years of age and older
- Dosage and conditions of administration: In accordance with the summary of product characteristics of the product administered and/or relevant national guidelines issued by the National Immunisation Advisory Committee.
- Place of administration: Any suitable and appropriate place, having regard to public convenience and the need to protect the health and safety of the public.

Regulation 4 of the Regulations of 2023 amends the Twelfth Schedule by inserting the following entry:

- Medicinal product: Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 dispersion for injection COVID-19 Vaccine (recombinant, adjuvanted)
- Route of administration: Dispersion for injection
- Form and presentation of product administered: Intramuscular injection
- Indication for which the medicinal product may be administered: Active immunisation to prevent COVID-19 caused by SARS-CoV-2 in individuals 12 years of age and older
- Dosage and conditions of administration: In accordance with the summary of product characteristics of the product administered and/or relevant national guidelines issued by the National Immunisation Advisory Committee.

These amendments update the relevant schedules in relation to the COVID-19 vaccines to include the Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 COVID-19 vaccine.

The Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 vaccine is listed in the Eighth Schedule (as amended by Regulation 3 of the Regulations of 2023) to the Principal Regulations. The entry for Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 is as follows:

The passage indicates that the Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 vaccine is administered via intramuscular injection and is indicated for active immunisation to prevent COVID-19 caused by SARS-CoV-2 in individuals 12 years of age and older. The dosage and conditions of administration are in accordance with the summary of product characteristics of the product administered and/or relevant national guidelines issued by the National Immunisation Advisory Committee.

Additionally, the passage states that the vaccine can be administered in any suitable and appropriate place, having regard to public convenience and the need to protect the health and safety of the public and safely administer the product.

Therefore, the administrative and clinical conditions governing the administration of the Nuvaxovid XBB.1.5 vaccine under the amended Schedules are:

1. The vaccine is administered via intramuscular injection.
2. The vaccine is indicated for active immunisation to prevent COVID-19 caused by SARS-CoV-2 in individuals 12 years of age and older.
3. The dosage and conditions of administration are in accordance with the summary of product characteristics of the product administered and/or relevant national guidelines issued by the National Immunisation Advisory Committee.
4. The vaccine can be administered in any suitable and appropriate place, having regard to public convenience and the need to protect the health and safety of the public and safely administer the product.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, a person may lawfully perform actions otherwise prohibited by the Council Regulation according to Regulation 4 of these Regulations if they have received an authorisation under Article 4(1), 4a(1), or 7(1) of the Council Regulation. 

This is explicitly stated in the passages, particularly in the following passages:

- Passage 4: "Notwithstanding Regulation 3, a person who has received an authorisation under Article 4(1), 4a(1) or 7(1) of the Council Regulation may, subject to compliance with the terms and conditions of such authorisation, do such of the things as are so authorised."
- Passage 4: "Notwithstanding Regulation 3, a person who has received an authorisation under Article 4(1), 4a(1) or 7(1) of the Council Regulation may, subject to compliance with the terms and conditions of such authorisation, do such of the things as are so authorised."
- Passage 4: "Notwithstanding Regulation 3, a person who has received an authorisation under Article 4(1), 4a(1) or 7(1) of the Council Regulation may, subject to compliance with the terms and conditions of such authorisation, do such of the things as are so authorised."

Therefore, a person who has received an authorisation under Article 4(1), 4a(1), or 7(1) of the Council Regulation may perform actions that would otherwise be prohibited by the Council Regulation, provided they comply with the terms and conditions of the authorisation.
