EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures contained 
in Council Regulation (EU) No. 1210/2003 of 7 July 2003, as amended, 
regarding restrictive measures concerning Iraq. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulation or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provides for appropriate penalties.

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures 
contained in Council Regulation (EU) No 224/2014 as amended, regarding 
restrictive measures concerning Central African Republic. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provides for appropriate 
penalties.

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures contained 
in Council Regulation (EC) No. 147/2003 as amended and Council Regulation 
(EU) No. 356/2010 as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning 
Somalia. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the powers of competent authorities to issue directions for the purposes of administering and enforcing sanctions are as follows:

Competent authorities of the State may issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. These directions may be addressed to any individual or entity that is subject to the sanctions.

The specific regulations that provide for these powers include:

* Council Regulation (EU) No. 1210/2003 of 7 July 2003, as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Iraq.
* Council Regulation (EC) No. 147/2003 as amended and Council Regulation (EU) No. 356/2010 as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Somalia.
* Council Regulation (EU) No. 753/2011 as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Afghanistan.
* Council Regulation (EU) No. 224/2014 as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Central African Republic.

These regulations provide that competent authorities may issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions, and create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities with regard to implementation of the sanctions.

Therefore, the answer to the question is:

Competent authorities of the State have the power to issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions, and these directions may be addressed to any individual or entity that is subject to the sanctions.

This evidence is taken to have been signed by the person purporting to have signed it, unless the contrary is shown.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the powers and duties of the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment that are delegated by this Order are as follows:

- The powers (other than the power to prosecute an offence) and duties conferred on the Minister by or under the enactments specified in Part 1 of the Schedule, by or under the provision of the enactment specified in Part 2 of the Schedule, and under the Regulations specified in Part 3 of the Schedule (as per the 2020 Order) are delegated to Robert Troy, Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

- The powers (other than the power to prosecute an offence) and duties conferred on the Minister by or under the enactments specified in Part 1 of the Schedule, and under the Regulations specified in Part 2 of the Schedule (as per the 2023 Order) are delegated to Neale Richmond, Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

There are no explicit exclusions mentioned in the provided passages.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The Ministers and Secretaries (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1977, provides, inter 
alia, for the delegation of powers and duties from Ministers to Ministers of State 
by way of a Government Order. Such Orders are normally made where a 
Minister of State is expected to carry out statutory functions on behalf of a 
Minister. It should be noted that every power or duty delegated continues to be 
vested in the Minister of the Government concurrently with the Minister of State 
and may be exercised or performed by either. This Order provides for the 
delegation of functions relating to the Irish Language and the Gaeltacht by the 
Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister 
of State with responsibility for Gaeilge and the Gaeltacht.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures 
contained in Council Regulation (EU) No 2015/1755 regarding restrictive 
measures concerning Burundi. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provides for appropriate 
penalties.

(2) A person who contravenes a condition of an authorisation granted under

3. (1) A person who contravenes a provision of the Council Regulation

Answer:
A person may lawfully perform acts that would otherwise contravene the Council Regulation concerning Burundi under the following conditions:

1. When the competent authorities of the State issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions, and the person complies with those directions.
2. When the person has been granted an authorisation under a provision of the Council Regulation, and they comply with the conditions of that authorisation.

These conditions are outlined in the European Union (Restrictive Measures concerning Burundi) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 697 of 2022), which revoke and re-enact the relevant provisions. Specifically, the Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions, and that a person who contravenes a provision of the Council Regulation or a condition of an authorisation granted under the Council Regulation shall be guilty of an offence.

It is essential to note that the Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to implementation of the sanctions, and provide for appropriate penalties. Therefore, it is crucial to ensure compliance with the Regulations and the Council Regulation to avoid any potential consequences.

Answer:
To determine the penalties for failing to comply with a direction issued by a competent authority under these Regulations, we must refer to the relevant passages.

Passage 52(6) states: "A direction shall be complied with within such period as may be specified in the direction." This implies that the direction itself will specify the deadline for compliance.

Passage 52(8) states: "Where a person confirms compliance under paragraph (7), the competent authority shall, on being satisfied that the person has so complied, give notice to the person confirming that compliance." This suggests that if a person fails to comply with the direction, they will not be able to confirm compliance.

Passage 52(9) states: "A person on whom a direction has been served may appeal the direction in accordance with Regulation 53." This implies that if a person fails to comply with the direction, they may appeal the direction, but this does not necessarily imply a penalty for non-compliance.

However, Passage 12(5)(f) states: "state that a failure to comply with the direction is an offence under Regulation 15," and Passage 14(5)(f) states: "state that a failure to comply with the direction is an offence under Regulation 18." This implies that failing to comply with a direction is an offence under the Regulations.

Therefore, the penalties for failing to comply with a direction issued by a competent authority under these Regulations are:

- A direction shall specify the deadline for compliance (Passage 52(6)).
- If a person fails to comply with the direction, they will not be able to confirm compliance (Passage 52(8)).
- Failing to comply with a direction is an offence under the Regulations (Passages 12(5)(f) and 14(5)(f)).
- A person may appeal the direction if they fail to comply (Passages 52(9) and 14(9)).

In summary, the penalties for failing to comply with a direction issued by a competent authority under these Regulations include the failure to confirm compliance, the specification of a deadline for compliance, and the designation of the failure to comply as an offence under the Regulations.

However, I can provide some general information on the topic. These measures are implemented through various regulations, including the ones mentioned in the passages.

To act lawfully despite a general prohibition, a person may need to obtain an authorisation or exemption from the relevant authorities. Unfortunately, the passages do not provide specific information on the conditions for obtaining an authorisation or exemption. Answer:
To determine the penalties applicable to a person convicted under these Regulations, we need to consider the various passages that outline the penalties for different types of offences.

For a person guilty of an offence under these Regulations (other than an offence under Regulation 19(9)), the penalties are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the person is liable to a class A fine (as outlined in Regulation 20(1)(a) and Regulation 15(2)(a)).
- On conviction on indictment, the person is liable to a fine not exceeding €250,000 (as outlined in Regulation 20(1)(b) and Regulation 15(2)(b)).

However, for a person guilty of an offence under Regulation 19(9), the penalties are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the person is liable to a Class A fine (as outlined in Regulation 20(2)).

Additionally, Regulation 3A outlines penalties for a person guilty of an offence under these Regulations, which are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the person is liable to a class A fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both (as outlined in Regulation 3A(a)).
- On conviction on indictment, the person is liable to a fine not exceeding €50,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or both (as outlined in Regulation 3A(b)).

Regulation 49 outlines penalties for a person who commits an offence under these Regulations, which are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the person is liable to a class A fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or both (as outlined in Regulation 49(a)).
- On conviction on indictment, the person is liable to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or both (as outlined in Regulation 49(b)).

Regulation 4 outlines penalties for a person who is guilty of an offence under Regulation 3, which are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the person is liable to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both (as outlined in Regulation 4(a)).
- On conviction on indictment, the person is liable to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or both (as outlined in Regulation 4(b)).

Lastly, Regulation 19 outlines penalties for a person who commits an offence under these Regulations, which are as follows:

- On summary conviction, the person is liable to a class B fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, or both (as outlined in Regulation 19(1)(a)).
- On conviction on indictment, the person is liable to a fine not exceeding €500,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, or both (as outlined in Regulation 19(1)(b)).

In summary, the penalties for a person convicted under these Regulations differ depending on the type of offence and the level of conviction.

Amendment to Article 9 of Principal Regulations
Answer:
The 2024 amendments to the Local Government (Audit Committee) Regulations alter the committee's engagement with Limerick City and County Council officials under the new mayoral system in the following ways:

1. **Separate meetings with the Mayor**: The audit committee must now meet separately at least annually with the Mayor of Limerick City and County Council, in addition to the other officials mentioned in Article 11(2) of the Principal Regulations. This is specified in the amended Article 11(2) of the Principal Regulations.

2. **Annual meeting with local parliamentary representatives**: The Chief Executive, together with the Cathaoirleach (or Príomh Comhairleoir) of the county council or city council, and the Mayor of Limerick City and County Council, shall arrange to meet with local parliamentary representatives as a group at least annually. This is specified in the amended Article 12 of the Principal Regulations.

3. **Amended definitions**: The amendments also introduce new definitions for "Mayor", "Príomh Comhairleoir", and "director general" in the context of Limerick City and County Council, which are specified in the amended Article 3 of the Principal Regulations.

4. **Duty to send reports to the Mayor**: On completion of the report prepared under Article 15(1) of the Principal Regulations, it shall be the duty of the Chairperson to send copies to the Chief Executive, in the case of Limerick City and County Council, to the Mayor, and to the local authority for consideration at the next practicable meeting. This is specified in the amended Article 15(2) of the Principal Regulations.

5. **Review of findings and recommendations**: The audit committee must review relevant findings and recommendations of the National Oversight and Audit Commission and the response of the Chief Executive, and, where applicable, the Mayor of Limerick City and County Council, to such findings and recommendations, and take further action as appropriate. This is specified in the amended Article 9(f) of the Principal Regulations.

These amendments reflect the changes introduced by the Local Government (Mayor of Limerick) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 2024 and are intended to facilitate the audit committee's engagement with Limerick City and County Council officials under the new mayoral system.

The general conditions attached to a Wireless Telegraphy (Telemetry Licence) that a Licensee must comply with to avoid enforcement action are specified in Regulation 7 of the Wireless Telegraphy (Telemetry Licence) Regulations, 2024 (S.I. 266 of 2024).

However, as the provided passages do not explicitly list the conditions, we can infer that the conditions are likely to be similar to those outlined in other Wireless Telegraphy Regulations, such as the Wireless Telegraphy (Mobile Radio Systems) Regulations, 2002 (S.I. No. 435 of 2002) and the Wireless Telegraphy (Liberalised Use and Related Licences in the 700 MHz Duplex, 2.1 GHz, 2.3 GHz and 2.6 GHz Bands) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 264 of 2021).

Based on the structure and content of these Regulations, the Licensee must comply with the following general conditions:

1. The Licensee shall ensure that it complies with all of the conditions contained within the Regulations and within Parts 1 to 4 of the Licence.
2. The Licensee shall ensure that it makes payment of all fees as detailed in the Regulations.
3. The Licensee shall not work or use the Apparatus detailed in Part 2 of the Licence, as specified in the Wireless Telegraphy (Liberalised Use and Related Licences in the 700 MHz Duplex, 2.1 GHz, 2.3 GHz and 2.6 GHz Bands) Regulations 2021 (S.I. No. 264 of 2021).
4. The Licensee shall ensure that it complies with all of the technical conditions of the Mobile Radio System, as specified in Part V of the Licence.
5. The Licensee shall ensure that it complies with all of the loading criteria, if applicable, as specified in Part VI of the Licence.
6. The Licensee shall ensure that it complies with the Roll-Out Plan, if applicable, as specified in Part VII of the Licence.

It is essential to note that these conditions are inferred and may not be an exhaustive list. The Licensee must refer to the specific Wireless Telegraphy Regulations and the Licence Conditions specified by the Commission in accordance with the Transfer and Lease Regulations to ensure compliance.

Answer:
To establish themselves as an eligible family member under the Institutional Burials Act 2022, an applicant may provide the following forms of evidence:

1. Public records, including:
   - Birth certificates
   - Marriage certificates
   - Death certificates
   These records must be issued under section 13 of the Civil Registration Act 2004.

2. Where public records are not available or deemed insufficient, the applicant may provide other records, including:
   - Institutional records
   - Medical records
   - Baptismal records

3. In cases where the provided documents are incomplete or insufficient, the Director may request an affidavit from the applicant with necessary information to establish their eligibility.

4. The Director may also use the powers provided under sections 27 and 29 of the Act to support the assessment of evidence provided by the applicant.

It is essential to note that the Director's decision on the sufficiency of the evidence is final.

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to follow the procedures outlined in the passages provided.

A Director must follow the procedures outlined in Regulation 5 of the Institutional Burials Act 2022 for the purposes of contacting eligible family members who may wish to object to participation in an Identification Programme.

The procedures include:

1. Requesting contact information from another eligible family member of the same deceased person who has made a notification to the Director under section 42(1)(b) of the Act (Regulation 5(2)(a)).
2. Using evidence provided by another eligible family member of the same deceased person under section 42(1)(f) of the Act (Regulation 5(2)(b)).
3. Using the powers provided under sections 27 and 29 of the Act for the purposes of making contact (Regulation 5(2)(c)).
4. Identifying additional means by which contact information can be obtained (Regulation 5(2)(d)).

If contact information is obtained, the Director must attempt to make contact with the eligible family member by means that he or she considers appropriate (Regulation 5(3)).

The Director must provide the eligible family member with information about the Identification Programme, their right to object, and the deadline for receipt of an objection (Regulation 5(3)).

If the Director is unable to make contact with an eligible family member after following these procedures, he or she may conclude that it is not possible to make contact (Regulation 5(6)).

Therefore, the procedures that a Director must follow to contact eligible family members who may wish to object to participation in an Identification Programme include requesting contact information, using evidence provided by another eligible family member, using the powers provided under sections 27 and 29 of the Act, and identifying additional means by which contact information can be obtained.

1. These Regulations may be cited as the National Milk Agency (Election 

Day) Regulations 2021.
Answer:
These Regulations redefine the constituencies entitled to elect producer members to the National Milk Agency and introduce procedural changes regarding the conduct of the election.

The constituencies are established by substituting Regulation 4(2) of the National Milk Agency (Conduct of Elections) Regulations 1997 (S.I. No. 185 of 1997) with new provisions. The constituencies are defined as follows:

- Registered producers who have supplied raw milk for heat treatment for liquid consumption to one or more of the following companies comprise a constituency and are entitled to elect 3 producer members to the Board of the National Milk Agency:
  - Tirlán Limited
  - Lakeland Dairies Co-Operative Society Limited
  - Aurivo Co-operative Society Limited
  - Glenisk Limited

- Registered producers who have supplied raw milk for heat treatment for liquid consumption to one or more of the following companies comprise a constituency and are entitled to elect 2 producer members to the Board of the National Milk Agency:
  - The Village Dairy Limited
  - Mossfield Organic Farm Ltd.
  - Bainne Codladh Ltd.
  - Arrabawn Co-operative Society Limited
  - Clona Dairy Products Society Limited
  - Dairygold Co-operative Society Limited (as agent for Tirlán Limited)
  - Dawn Dairies Limited (Kerry Creameries Limited T/A Kerry Agribusiness – Dairies)
  - Lee Strand Co-operative Creamery Limited
  - North Cork Co-operative Creameries Limited
  - Centenary Thurles Co-operative Society Limited (Thurles Fresh Milk Limited)

Procedural changes introduced include:

- The amendment of Regulation 13 by substituting "the closing date for receipt of nomination papers" for "the nomination day".
- The amendment of Regulation 20(a) by substituting "the place and times for the counting of votes, the date ("the ballot return day") by which completed ballot papers must be received by the returning officer;" for "the place and times for the counting of votes;".
- The amendment of Regulation 28(1) by substituting "On the working day next following the ballot return day, or such other day as may be approved by the returning officer" for "At the hour of 2.00 p.m. on the day next following the day on which the return of all ballot papers issued at an election to the returning officer is completed".

These changes were made by the National Milk Agency (Conduct of Elections) (Amendment) Regulations 2024 (S.I. No. 340 of 2024).

Answer:
The new provisions introduced by these Regulations regarding the timing for receipt of nomination papers, ballot return day, and the counting of votes in National Milk Agency elections are as follows:

- The closing date for receipt of nomination papers is now specified, replacing the previous nomination day.
- The ballot return day is now defined, specifying the date by which completed ballot papers must be received by the returning officer.
- The counting of votes will now take place on the working day next following the ballot return day, or such other day as may be approved by the returning officer.

These changes are made by amending Regulations 13, 20(a), and 28(1) of the National Milk Agency (Conduct of Elections) Regulations 1997 (S.I. No. 185 of 1997).

Answer:
These Regulations prescribe distinct forms of notice for the following specific categories of offences under section 2 of the Immigration Act 2003:

1. Offence under section 2(1)(b): The form of notice set out in Schedule 2 is prescribed for this offence.
2. Offence under section 2(1)(c): The form of notice set out in Schedule 3 is prescribed for this offence.
3. Offence under section 2(3)(a): The form of notice set out in Schedule 4 is prescribed for this offence.
4. Offence under section 2(3)(b): The form of notice set out in Schedule 5 is prescribed for this offence.

The statutory authority that empowers the creation of these forms of notice is section 3(1) of the Immigration Act 2003. 

The Minister for Justice, Helen McEntee, has given these Regulations under her official seal on 7 August 2024.

consideration of proceedings as the Court may afford, the Court may: 

(a) make provision for eligibility to apply for a date on the basis of

(v) whether, to what extent and by what date any such issues or

(vi)

(d) make provision for a specified time limit for the hearing (save 
where oral evidence is required, in which case a time estimate 
shall be specified (the “oral evidence procedure”)); and/or 

(e) make provision as to whether the matter should be heard in or

basis of such time limit as the Court may fix (the “expedited 
procedure”), or over two (or if necessary, more) court days on the 
basis of such time limit as the Court may fix (the “standard 
procedure”). 

(5) Subject to any order of the Court to another effect in any individual case,

(b)

the expedited procedure shall apply as a default to the following

(6) An order providing for a priority procedure may be made at any time, 
including at the stage of an intended action or in the case of a judicial review, 
prior to the grant of leave. Such an order will normally be made on notice, but if 
made otherwise than on notice, it will be subject to the right of any other party 
to apply. For the avoidance of doubt, such an order is not limited to the List to 
Fix Dates. 

(7) Where a priority procedure applies, all issues will as a default be 
addressed in a unitary manner against all opposing parties, unless the Court 
otherwise orders on application by any party. 

(8) Any party may apply that any given proceedings be afforded a procedure 

other than the default procedure applying to such proceedings.

(9) Where the parties (or if applicable the parties participating in the relevant 
module or hearing) agree on a particular mode of trial, the Court shall make such 
order, unless it is impracticable to do so. If the Court does not make such an 
agreed order it shall direct the next most expeditious mode of trial that is 
practicable. 

(10) Where the parties (or if applicable the parties participating in the 
relevant module or hearing) disagree on the mode of trial, the Court shall 
normally provide for the mode of trial that is the most expeditious of the options 
proposed, save in respect of the written procedure, and subject to the interests of 
justice, including the requirement to apply the most expeditious procedure in 
national law to matters to which Article 16(6) of Directive (EU) 2018/2001 
relates. If the Court does not make an order in terms of the most expeditious 
option proposed, it shall direct the next most expeditious mode of trial that is 
practicable. 

(11) Unless the Court otherwise directs, in the case of modularised 
proceedings, any order disposing of a particular module shall not be perfected 
until the making of the final order.

7. (1) Proceedings shall be commenced in the Planning & Environment List 
by the filing of the appropriate initiating document as set out in these Rules or 
other enactment. 

(2) Where the procedural or statutory requirements applicable to the 
proceedings are such that the proceedings may be commenced by originating 
notice of motion without leave of the Court, including by way of Part 9 judicial 
review, the applicant shall commence Planning & Environment proceedings by 
filing the originating notice of motion, together with a Statement of Grounds and 
such other documents as are required by this Order. The Central Office shall 
assign a return date for the motion, if practicable in consultation with the List 
Registrar. 

(3) Where the procedural or statutory requirements applicable to the 
proceedings are such that the proceedings may be commenced otherwise than by 
originating notice of motion, but without leave of the Court, the applicant shall 
commence Planning & Environment proceedings by filing the appropriate 
initiating pleading and such other documents as are required by this Order. The 
Central Office shall assign a return date for the proceedings, if practicable in 
consultation with the List Registrar. 

(4) Where the procedural or statutory requirements applicable to the 
proceedings are such that the application for leave to bring the proceedings 
requires to be made on notice, the applicant shall commence Planning & 
Environment proceedings by filing a Statement of Grounds and a notice of 
motion, together with such other documents as are required by this Order, and 
shall before or as soon as possible after issuing the proceedings apply to the List 
Registrar for a hearing date in the Planning & Environment List for that 
application and shall serve the other parties with the proceedings in due time as 
prescribed by these Rules in advance of that date. 

(5) Where the procedural or statutory requirements applicable to the 
proceedings are such that the application for leave to bring the proceedings 
requires to be made ex parte, the applicant shall commence Planning & 
Environment proceedings by filing a Statement of Grounds, together with such 
other documents as are required by this Order, and shall before or as soon as 
possible after issuing the proceedings apply to the List Registrar for a hearing 
date in the Planning & Environment List for that application. 

(6) A notice of motion required under this rule shall be served four clear days 

in advance of the hearing on all other parties. 

(7) For the purposes of this Order, “filing” means the filing in the Office of 
the document concerned, or the first mention of the matter to the Court, 
whichever is earlier, on the basis that where a matter is mentioned to the Court 
prior to the filing of papers in the Office, the Court shall be deemed to have taken 
the papers as having been filed in Court that day, subject to formal filing in the 
Office as soon as convenient thereafter, unless expressly ordered otherwise by 
the Court. 

 [246] 13 

(8) The initiating document and all other pleadings and affidavits shall be 

entitled in the manner specified in rule 4.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Currently, article 182 of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and 
Control) Regulations 2007, provides that the prescribed time for making a claim 
for State Pension (Contributory) is within the period of 3 months before and 3 
months after that person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). 

Failure to make a claim for State Pension (Contributory) within the prescribed 
time means that section 241(2) of the Social Welfare Act 2007 applies. This 
provides that where a person fails to claim within the time prescribed, that person 
will not be paid in respect of any period more than 6 months before the claim is 
made. 

These Regulations amend the prescribed time for making a claim for State 
Pension (Contributory) so that a claim may be made up to 6 months before the 
date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). 

From end October 2024, an online application form for state pension 
(contributory) and state pension (non-contributory) will be available to 
claimants. To align state pension (contributory) application timelines with the 
state pension (non-contributory), it is necessary to increase the prescribed time 
for state pension (contributory) from 3 to 6 months. 

The prescribed period after which a person becomes entitled to State Pension 
(Contributory) in which to make a claim remains at 3 months.

Answer:
These Regulations make amendments to Article 182 of the Principal Regulations concerning the prescribed time for making claims to State pensions. Specifically, the Regulations amend the prescribed time for making a claim for State Pension (Contributory) so that a claim may be made up to 6 months before the date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). 

The prescribed period after which a person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory) in which to make a claim remains at 3 months. This means that a claim for State Pension (Contributory) can be made within the period of 6 months before and 3 months after the date the person becomes entitled to the pension.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Part 4 of the Social Welfare (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2023 (No. 37 of 
2023)) amends the Social Welfare Consolidation Act 2005 to facilitate– 

access to the State pension (contributory), in certain circumstances, for longterm carers, 

the introduction of flexibility to State pension (contributory) to allow a person 
to defer claiming the State pension (contributory) up to the age of 70. 

continued access to specified weekly social welfare payments after reaching 
pensionable age and during pension deferral. 

the phased transition to the total contributions approach, in the calculation of 
the State pension (contributory). 

These Regulations make consequential changes to articles 31 and 88 of the 
Social Welfare (Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) Regulations 1996 
(S.I. No. 312 of 1996)) arising from changes to the system of PRSI which 
follow from the Part 4 primary legislation.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Part 4 of the Social Welfare (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2023 (No. 37 of 
2023) amends the Social Welfare Consolidation Act 2005 to facilitate– 

• 

• 

• 

the introduction of flexibility to State Pension (Contributory) to allow a 
person to defer claiming the State Pension (Contributory) up to the age 
of 70, 

continued access to specified weekly social welfare payments after 
reaching pensionable age and during pension deferral, 

the phased transition to the total contributions approach, in the 
calculation of the State Pension (Contributory). 

Consequential to the changes to State Pension (Contributory), these Regulations 
confirm that a person who has attained the age of 65 years and has not yet 
attained the age of 66 years, who would otherwise qualify for Jobseeker’s 
Benefit or Jobseeker’s Benefit (self-employed), will not be obliged to meet the 
ongoing requirements of those schemes in relation to availability for work, 
genuinely seeking work, signing-on or activation. 

 In addition, they provide that a person who has attained the age of 65 years and 
has not yet attained the age of 66 years, who is in receipt of Jobseeker’s Benefit 
or Jobseeker’s Benefit (Self-Employed), is not disqualified for receipt of such 
payment where his or her temporary absence from the State exceeds two weeks, 
provided he or she does not engage in gainful employment during that absence.

(Consolidated Contributions and Insurability) Regulations 1996 (S.I. No. 312 
of 1996)) restricting the extent to which employment contributions can be 
credited to an insured person who has attained pensionable age and— 

(a) whose entry into insurance had not occurred prior to attaining 

pensionable age; 

(b) 

is claiming illness benefit, partial capacity benefit, jobseeker’s 
benefit or jobseeker’s benefit (self-employed); 

(c) 

is attending certain approved courses of education or training; 

(d) 

is employed as a volunteer development worker. 

These restrictions take effect from 1 January 2024: the date on which the 
possibility for such credited contributions might first arise by virtue of the 
changes made by Part 4 of the Social Welfare (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act

2. These Regulations come into operation on 1 January 2024. 

State pension (contributory) – miscellaneous amendments

4. Article 182 of the Principal Regulations (amended by article 7 of the 
Regulations of 2019) is amended by the substitution of the following paragraphs 
for paragraph (a): 

“(a) in the case of State pension (contributory), the period commencing 6 months 
before and ending 3 months after the date on which, apart from satisfying the 
condition of making a claim, the claimant becomes entitled thereto, 

(ab) in the case of State pension (transition) and invalidity pension, the period 
commencing 3 months before and ending 3 months after the date on which, apart

 from satisfying the condition of making a claim, the claimant becomes entitled

Minister for Social Protection. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4 [584]

1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the Social Welfare (Consolidated 
Claims, Payments and Control) (Amendment) (No. 12) (State Pension 
(Contributory) – Long-Term Carer’s Qualifying Contribution) Regulations
Answer:
According to the explanatory note, these Regulations alter the prescribed time limits for claiming the State Pension (Contributory) by amending article 182 of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) Regulations 2007. The prescribed time for making a claim for State Pension (Contributory) is now extended to 6 months before the date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory), in addition to the existing 3 months after entitlement.

The rationale for the change is to align the State Pension (Contributory) application timelines with the State Pension (Non-Contributory) application timelines, as an online application form for both pensions will be available from end October 2024.

In summary, the prescribed time for claiming State Pension (Contributory) has been extended to 6 months before entitlement, in addition to the existing 3 months after entitlement, to facilitate online applications and align with the State Pension (Non-Contributory) application timelines.

Answer:
The Student Support Regulations 2025 define 'approved institutions' for purposes of grant eligibility under the Student Support Act 2011 as institutions that are recognized by the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science. 

According to Regulation 3 of the Student Support Regulations, "approved institution" shall be construed in accordance with section 7(1)(a), (b), (ba) and (c) of the Act and Regulation 3 of the Regulations. 

Section 7(1)(a), (b), (ba) and (c) of the Act states that an approved institution is a recognized awarding body in the State, which includes:

- Quality and Qualifications Ireland (QQI)
- One of the universities in the State
- One of the technological universities in the State
- The Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland
- One of the Institutes of Technology

Therefore, an institution must be recognized by the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science and meet the criteria outlined in section 7(1)(a), (b), (ba) and (c) of the Act to be considered an 'approved institution' for purposes of grant eligibility under the Student Support Act 2011.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

Answer:
A person may lawfully perform acts that would otherwise constitute an offence under these Regulations if they can demonstrate that reasonable steps were taken to comply with the relevant obligation or direction, or it was not possible to comply with the relevant obligation or direction.

This exception is outlined in Regulation 6(2) of these Regulations, which states that it is a defence to show that reasonable steps were taken to comply with the relevant obligation or direction, or it was not possible to comply with the relevant obligation or direction. This defence is specifically applicable to proceedings for an offence under Regulation 6 in relation to compliance with obligations under Article 13(1) and (6) or 14(2), (6), or (7) of the Mobile Phone Roaming Regulation, or a direction of the Regulator under Regulation 3(2) of these Regulations.

Therefore, if a person can demonstrate that they have taken reasonable steps to comply with the relevant obligation or direction, or it was not possible to comply with the relevant obligation or direction, they may be able to lawfully perform acts that would otherwise constitute an offence under these Regulations.

Court sitting in Dublin, be for the first opportunity after the expiration of

Answer:
To prepare a Notice of Appeal to the High Court sitting in Dublin, the following core particulars must be stated about the parties and the decision appealed:

1. **Respondent Details**: Provide the relevant details for each respondent affected by the application for leave to appeal, including:
	* Respondent's full name
	* Original status of respondent in proceedings under appeal
	* Solicitor's name, firm, and contact information
	* Name of solicitor responsible for the appeal
	* Email address
	* Address (including Eircode)
	* Telephone number
	* Document Exchange number
	* If the respondent is not legally represented, provide their current postal address, email address, and telephone number
2. **Parties Involved**: Clearly indicate the roles of the parties involved, including:
	* Plaintiff
	* Defendant
	* Applicant
	* Petitioner
	* Respondent
	* Notice Party
3. **Notice of Appeal**: The notice of appeal must be served within ten days from the time permitted for service of the notice of appeal, and must be for the first opportunity after the expiration of this period.
4. **Listing Details**: Include the following details:
	* Date and time of the appeal
	* Location of the High Court (in this case, Dublin)
	* Signature and name of the person issuing the notice
	* Address of the person issuing the notice
5. **Service**: The notice of appeal must be served on the County Registrar, County of ..., and on the respondent at their address.

By including these core particulars, the Notice of Appeal to the High Court sitting in Dublin will be complete and compliant with the relevant regulations.

7. (1) Where, in the opinion of an Appeals Officer, an oral hearing is 
required, he or she shall, as soon as practicable, fix a date and make arrangements 
for the hearing, whether that be in person or by telephone or video call and give 
reasonable notice of the date, means, venue and time to the appellant. 

(2) An appellant may request an oral hearing and this request may be granted 

at the Appeals Officer’s discretion. 

(3) An appellant may represent himself or herself, or may, with the consent 
of the Appeals Officer, be accompanied or represented by another person at the 
oral hearing of his or her appeal. 

(4) Notwithstanding that an appellant may be represented by another person 
at the oral hearing of his or her appeal, the Appeals Officer may make enquiries 
directly of the appellant as he or she deems appropriate. 

(5) Any other person appearing to an Appeals Officer to be directly 

concerned may also attend the hearing. 

(6) A party to an appeal may make a request, in writing, accompanied by 
relevant documentation, for an adjournment of a hearing citing the reasons for

Employment 

by or under sections 11, 12 and 13 of the Industrial Development (Forfás

contained in any Act or instrument made under such Act and relating to any 
functions transferred by this Article shall, on and after the commencement of 
this Order, be construed as references to the Minister for Further and Higher 
Education, Research, Innovation and Science.

for Enterprise, Trade and Employment, the name of the Minister for Enterprise,

7. References to the Minister for Education contained in the memorandum 
and articles of association of any company and relating to any function 
transferred by this Order shall, on and after the commencement of this Order, be 
construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

7. References to the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport 
and Media contained in the constitution of any company and relating to any 
function transferred by this Order shall, from the commencement of this Order, 
be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and 
Employment.
Answer:
After this Order takes effect, statutory references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment and to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment should be construed as follows:

- References to the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media contained in any Act or instrument made under an Act and relating to any administration and business transferred by Article 3 should be construed as references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Article 2(2)).
- References to the Department of Education contained in any Act or instrument made under such Act and relating to any administration and business transferred by paragraph (1) of Article 2 should be construed as references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Article 2(2)).
- References to the Minister for Education contained in the memorandum and articles of association of any company and relating to any function transferred by this Order should be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Article 7).
- References to the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media contained in the constitution of any company and relating to any function transferred by this Order should be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Article 7).
- References to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment contained in the memorandum and articles of association of any company and relating to any function transferred by this Order should be construed as references to the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science (Article 7).
- References to the Minister for Education contained in the memorandum and articles of association of any company and relating to any function transferred by this Order should be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Article 7).

However, it is essential to note that Article 3(2) states that references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment contained in any Act or instrument made under such Act and relating to any functions transferred by Article 3 should be construed as references to the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science.

5. (1) Subject to the provisions of this bye-law, the Returning Officer shall 
be responsible for determining all questions of procedure, form, or manner in 
which the Election shall take place and shall have the duty to ensure the validity 
and integrity of the nomination and Election processes. He or she shall have all 
powers necessary to carry out such functions, responsibility and duty, and 
without prejudice to the generality thereof, shall have the power to make 
decisions with regard to the qualification or disqualification of candidates, the 
making of decisions in respect of valid or invalid votes, the conduct of the count, 
and all other matters which might arise during the course of the Election. 

(2) The Returning Officer shall determine the form and content of all 
nomination papers, ballots, declarations, instructions, advertisements and 
notices required to be issued in accordance with this bye-law. 

(3) The Returning Officer will set the date for establishing the Electoral 
register, the closing date for receipt of nominations, the date for the opening of 
the poll and the closing date for receipt of ballots and shall have power to adjust 
or revise such dates, should the Returning Officer deem fit in any particular 
circumstances. 

(4) The Returning Officer shall keep or cause to be kept appropriate records 

in connection with the Election. 

(5) The decision of the Returning Officer on any matters arising in respect 
of the conduct of the Election or otherwise in connection with any Election is 
final.

Answer:
To answer your question, the statutory powers of the Minister for Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht that are delegated under this Order are:

- The powers vested in the Minister for Culture, Heritage and the Gaeltacht by or under the Minister for Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Powers and Functions) Acts 2003 and 2007, section 2(1)(e) (in so far as it relates to supporting and promoting the development of the Islands) of the Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2007 (No. 32 of 2007), and section 5 (in so far as it relates to the functions transferred by this Order) of the Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands (Powers and Functions) Act 1998 (No. 7 of 1998).
- The powers vested in the Minister for Culture, Heritage and the Gaeltacht by or under the Social Welfare (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2010 (No. 28 of 2010), in so far as it relates to the functions transferred by this Order.

These statutory powers are delegated to Jerry Buttimer, Minister of State at the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht, as per the provisions of the Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht (Delegation of Ministerial Functions) Order 2025, Schedule Part 1 of the Acts of the Oireachtas and Part 2 of the instruments specified in the Schedule.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The Ministers and Secretaries (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1977, provides, inter 
alia, for the delegation of powers and duties from Ministers to Ministers of State 
by way of a Government Order. Such Orders are normally made where a 
Minister of State is expected to carry out statutory functions on behalf of a 
Minister. It should be noted that every power or duty delegated continues to be 
vested in the Minister of the Government concurrently with the Minister of State 
and may be exercised or performed by either. This Order provides for the 
delegation of functions relating to the Irish Language and the Gaeltacht by the 
Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister 
of State with responsibility for Gaeilge and the Gaeltacht.

1. This Order may be cited as the Enterprise, Trade and Employment 

(Delegation of Ministerial Functions) Order 2022.
Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the statutes and statutory instruments that fall within the scope of functions delegated under the Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Delegation of Ministerial Functions) Order 2020 and other related Orders are:

1. The Ministers and Secretaries (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1977 (Statutory Instrument Number: Not specified)
2. The Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Delegation of Ministerial Functions) Order 2020 (Statutory Instrument Number: Not specified)
3. The Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Delegation of Ministerial Functions) (No. 2) Order 2020 (Statutory Instrument Number: Not specified)
4. The Health (Delegation of Ministerial Functions) (No. 2) Order 2020 (Statutory Instrument Number: Not specified)
5. The Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Delegation of Ministerial Functions) Order 2022 (Statutory Instrument Number: Not specified)

These Orders delegate powers and duties from Ministers to Ministers of State by way of a Government Order, as provided for in the Ministers and Secretaries (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1977. The specific functions delegated under these Orders include:

* The delegation of functions relating to the Irish Language and the Gaeltacht by the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister of State with responsibility for Gaeilge and the Gaeltacht.
* The delegation of functions relating to Sport Ireland by the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister of State with responsibility for Sport and the Gaeltacht.
* The delegation of functions relating to Sport Ireland by the Minister for Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister of State with responsibility for Sport.

It is worth noting that every power or duty delegated continues to be vested in the Minister of the Government concurrently with the Minister of State and may be exercised or performed by either.

15. (1) Infrastructure charges and user charges for heavy-duty vehicles shall 

be varied in accordance with this Regulation. 

(2) Without prejudice to paragraph (1), the following shall be established for 

each type of heavy-duty vehicle the following CO2 emission classes: 

(a) CO2 emission class 1 – vehicles that do not belong to any of the 
CO2 emission classes referred to under subparagraphs (b) to (e); 

(b) CO2 emission class 2 – vehicles of the vehicle sub-group sg 
registered for the first time in the reporting period of the year Y 
with CO2 emissions more than 5% below the emission reduction 
trajectory for the reporting period of the year Y and the vehicle 
sub-group sg but not belonging to any of the CO2 emission classes 
referred to under subparagraphs (c), (d) and (e); 

(c) CO2 emission class 3 – vehicles of the vehicle sub-group sg 
registered for the first time in the reporting period of the year Y 
with CO2 emissions more than 8% below the emission reduction 
trajectory for the reporting period of the year Y and the vehicle 
sub-group sg not belonging to any of the CO2 emission classes 
referred to under subparagraphs (d) and (e); 

(d) CO2 emission class 4 – low-emission heavy-duty vehicles; and 

(e) CO2 emission class 5 – zero-emission vehicles. 

The classification of a vehicle belonging to CO2 emission class 2 or 3 shall be 
reassessed every 6 years after the date of its first registration and that, where 
relevant, the vehicle is reclassified in the relevant emission class on the basis of 
the thresholds applicable at that time. Reclassification shall, with regard to a 

 
 
 16 [601] 

user charge, take effect at the latest on its first day of validity on or after the day 
of that reclassification. 

(3) Without prejudice to paragraph (1), reduced charges shall apply to 

vehicles in CO2 emission classes 2, 3, and 4 and 5, as follows: 

(a) CO2 emission class 2 – 5% to 15% reduction compared to the 

charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1; 

(b) CO2 emission class 3 – 15% to 30% reduction compared to the 

charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1; 

(c) CO2 emission class 4 – 30% to 50% reduction compared to the 

charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1; and 

(d) CO2 emission class 5 – 50% to 75% reduction compared to the 

charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1. 

Where the infrastructure charge or the user charge is also varied according to the 
Euro emission class, the reductions referred to in the first subparagraph shall 
apply as compared to the charge applied to the strictest Euro emission standards. 

(4) The variations referred to in this Regulation shall not be designed to 

generate additional revenues. 

(5) By way of derogation from paragraph (1), the Minister may decide not 
to apply the requirement of varying the infrastructure charge in accordance with 
paragraph (2) where an external-cost charge for CO2 emissions is levied and 
varied according to the reference values of the external-cost charge for CO2 
emissions in Annex IIIc. 

(6) On road sections where a vehicle is operated without CO2 emissions in a 
verifiable manner, reduced charges may apply to that vehicle in accordance with 
CO2 emission class 5. Where that option is being used, the charges applicable to 
CO2 emission class 1 shall be applied to that vehicle on other road sections. 

(7) The application of the variation of charges based on CO2 emissions 
referred to in this Regulation shall not be mandatory where another Union road 
transport fuel carbon-pricing measure applies. 

Tolls and user charges for other vehicle categories
Answer:
These Regulations introduce a new provision concerning eligible vehicles, specifically those that emit no CO2 tailpipe emissions. The new provision includes the following:

1. A green stripe on registration plates for eligible vehicles, as per Regulation 4(10) of the amended Vehicle Registration and Taxation Regulations, 1992 (S.I. No. 318 of 1992).
2. The classification of vehicles into CO2 emission classes, as per Regulation 15 of the amended Regulations. The classes are:
   - CO2 emission class 1: vehicles that do not belong to any of the other classes.
   - CO2 emission class 2: vehicles with CO2 emissions more than 5% below the emission reduction trajectory for the reporting period of the year Y.
   - CO2 emission class 3: vehicles with CO2 emissions more than 8% below the emission reduction trajectory for the reporting period of the year Y.
   - CO2 emission class 4: low-emission heavy-duty vehicles.
   - CO2 emission class 5: zero-emission vehicles.
3. Reduced charges for vehicles in CO2 emission classes 2, 3, 4, and 5, as per Regulation 15(3) of the amended Regulations. The reductions are:
   - CO2 emission class 2: 5% to 15% reduction compared to the charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1.
   - CO2 emission class 3: 15% to 30% reduction compared to the charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1.
   - CO2 emission class 4: 30% to 50% reduction compared to the charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1.
   - CO2 emission class 5: 50% to 75% reduction compared to the charge applicable for CO2 emission class 1.
4. The option for vehicles to operate without CO2 emissions on certain road sections, as per Regulation 15(6) of the amended Regulations. In this case, reduced charges may apply to the vehicle in accordance with CO2 emission class 5, and the charges applicable to CO2 emission class 1 shall be applied on other road sections.

1992 (S.I. No. 318 of 1992) to introduce a green stripe on registration plates for 
vehicles that emit no CO2 tailpipe emissions.

Answer:
According to the First Schedule amendments, the specifications that govern the green stripe and character dimensions on eligible vehicle registration plates are as follows:

- The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall be colour Pantone 7481c or a colour match that is as close as possible to this colour and shall be formed of reflex reflective material. (Paragraph 12A)
- The identification mark of an eligible vehicle may be displayed on a rectangular plate which shall correspond with either Diagram No. 5 or Diagram No. 6 shown below. (Paragraph 2B)
- The identification mark shall appear in black characters and each letter or figure shall have a height of not less than 65 millimetres and not more than 70 millimetres. (Paragraph 14)
- The stroke width of each letter or figure shall be not less than 9 millimetres and not more than 10 millimetres. (Paragraph 14)
- The total width of the space taken by each letter or figure (other than the letter “I” or the number “1”) shall be not less than 33 millimetres and not more than 50 millimetres. (Paragraph 14)
- The distances between adjoining figures shall be uniform and shall be not less than 8 millimetres. (Paragraph 14)
- The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall extend vertically from the inner edge of the black border at the top of the plate to the inner edge of the black border at the bottom of the plate and shall extend horizontally for a distance of 30 millimetres from the inner edge of the black border on the right-hand side of the plate. (Paragraph 16(h))
- The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall extend vertically from the lower edge of the blue background of the flag of the European Communities to the inner edge of the black border at the bottom of the plate and shall extend horizontally for a distance of 45 millimetres from the inner edge of the black border on the left-hand side of the plate. (Paragraph 17(l))

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025 do not modify the definition of 'relevant employer' or the timeline for reporting obligations.

However, the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 264 of 2022) are amended to substitute "50" for "150" in the definition of "relevant employer" and to substitute "5 months" for "6 months" in Regulation 6(1).

Therefore, the definition of 'relevant employer' is modified to include employers with 50 or more employees, and the timeline for reporting obligations is reduced to 5 months.

It is essential to note that the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025 came into operation on 31 May 2025, which is after the amendment made by the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) Regulations 2022.

This passage indicates that Regulation 2 has the legal effect of declaring the substances listed in the Schedule to be controlled drugs under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1977 (No. 12 of 1977).

The primary Act under which these substances are controlled is the Misuse of Drugs Act 1977 (No. 12 of 1977).

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the authority that may issue written directions for administering and enforcing these Regulations and the Council Regulation is a competent authority, following consultation with other competent authorities, as stated in passages 5, 6, and 6.

Additionally, the Authority, as mentioned in passage 4, may also issue directions to a road authority in relation to any matter arising under these Regulations or the Directive. The Authority shall consult with the road authority before issuing a direction.

The penalties for failing to comply with the directions within the specified time are as follows:

- A person who fails to comply with a direction may be liable to a penalty set out in paragraph (9) of passage 12, which is a class A fine.
- A person who causes or permits another person to contravene the terms of a direction may also be liable to a class A fine.

It is essential to note that the Minister may also give a direction in writing to the Authority in relation to any matter arising under these Regulations or the Directive, and the Authority shall comply with such direction.
